description: Whether using for personal email or work email as large business organization, this course covers everything one needs to become a skilled and informed user of Microsoft Outlook on the Web. This course is specifically for using Outlook through a web browser with either a paid subscription to Office 365 or a free mail account with Outlook.com.   Our hosts start with explaining the basic terminology and setup of email accounts and continue on to all areas of Outlook including managing email, contacts, calendars, and tasks.

episodes.description: Whether using for personal email or work email as large business organization, this course covers everything one needs to become a skilled and informed user of Microsoft Outlook on the Web. Our hosts start with explaining the basic terminology and setup of email accounts and continue on to all areas of Outlook including managing email, contacts, calendars, and tasks.
episodes.title: Overview

WEBVTT

1

We're also gonna talk about

an exchange servers, and Office 365 and

So we're also gonna be talking about
the interface of your mail in your

browser because this is out on the web.

So we will be taking
some time to go ahead and

23

I will also gonna go ahead and talk about
your account set-up which honestly,

they're really isn't much set-up to
do because you're already online.

And so, that's kinda of the nice thing.

We're also going to talk about
some emailing, all right.

That's probably a lot with Outlook is
known for so we're going to send and

We're also gonna be

We'll hopefully we'll try

be able to show you all the different

40
00:02:00.708 --> 00:02:02.470
We're also gonna talk about people.

Now if you're from back in the day,
what are people?

It's your contacts,
they're really the same thing.

We'll be creating new contacts,

And doing some comparing and

because there are some decent amount of

00:02:43.920 --> 00:02:45.480
And then we have our other topic,

57
00:02:52.650 --> 00:02:57.243
And any other miscellaneous items

59

Now who was this for?

00:03:09.403 --> 00:03:11.560

But you can see that I do

And I actually kinda cover quite

101

102

103

Extra things to always keep in mind,

104

106

108
00:05:42.322 --> 00:05:45.475
So sometimes right clicking

114
00:06:02.550 --> 00:06:05.530
You might have some other ways
that you might be able to do it.

115
00:06:05.530 --> 00:06:08.730
And I did throw in here the browsers.

116
00:06:08.730 --> 00:06:13.372
While there might not be too many

118
00:06:17.309 --> 00:06:22.304
A Microsoft product, versus let's

00:06:22.304 --> 00:06:27.234
a Mac with a Safari browser,
that could Have something to do with it.

120
00:06:27.234 --> 00:06:28.887
If you do any type of searching, and

121
00:06:28.887 --> 00:06:31.840
you can see that's one of my
bullet points right there.

122
00:06:31.840 --> 00:06:35.465
Searching for the answers, there's
always something that's gonna come up or

123

124
00:06:36.774 --> 00:06:38.930
You go out and you search for the web.

125
00:06:38.930 --> 00:06:41.394
And a lot of those forums that

126

127
00:06:43.278 --> 00:06:47.856
They're always gonna ask the people who
are asking questions in those forums,

128
00:06:47.856 --> 00:06:51.970

because it could make a difference.

129
00:06:51.970 --> 00:06:55.691
Maybe there are certain features that
are not available within that particular

130

131
00:06:57.757 --> 00:07:02.190
And another one that's always happening,

132
00:07:02.190 --> 00:07:04.404
Updates can throw things
all out of whack sometimes.

133
00:07:04.404 --> 00:07:08.372
That's actually happened to me right in

134

there's an Office update and
it's completely reconfigured everything.

135
00:07:12.291 --> 00:07:15.000
So it could happen, it will happen.

136
00:07:15.000 --> 00:07:19.372
And it might have some changes in what
you're looking at at the time that you're

137
00:07:19.372 --> 00:07:22.720

the time that I did the tutorial.

138
00:07:22.720 --> 00:07:27.283
And of course anytime we had any major
changes, we will always go ahead and

139
00:07:27.283 --> 00:07:29.720
update those episodes for you.

140
00:07:29.720 --> 00:07:32.695
And of course everybody has a different
reason for using Outlook, and

141
00:07:32.695 --> 00:07:35.230
you might not use it the same
way that somebody else uses it.

142
00:07:35.230 --> 00:07:37.887
But that's okay to eat its own,
and so I wanna try and

143
00:07:37.887 --> 00:07:40.020
give you all the different options.

144
00:07:40.020 --> 00:07:43.694
So just keep that in mind, like I don't
wanna use that feature, then don't,

145
00:07:43.694 --> 00:07:45.710
it's okay, you use it to your advantage.

146
00:07:45.710 --> 00:07:49.286
But the most part, but the most
important thing, try to have fun, or

147
00:07:49.286 --> 00:07:50.960
at least watch these episodes.

148
00:07:50.960 --> 00:07:54.064
We try to keep it light, and
have some playing around and

149
00:07:54.064 --> 00:07:57.710
making some jokes here and
there to try to keep your learning fun.

150
00:07:57.710 --> 00:07:59.138
Because I will tell you,

151
00:07:59.138 --> 00:08:02.950
I get just as frustrated sometimes
when something doesn't work.

152
00:08:02.950 --> 00:08:05.880
And so that's where you have to kinda
sit back and just kinda take a breath.

153
00:08:05.880 --> 00:08:10.107
And make sure that you always say,
this will figure it's self out,

154
00:08:10.107 --> 00:08:14.350
I will learn how to do this, and
just have fun with everything.

155
00:08:14.350 --> 00:08:16.679
And I hope to see you in some
episodes really, really soon.

156
00:08:16.679 --> 00:08:23.306
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore the differences among many of the products that are branded with the Outlook name.  Additionally, they discuss transformations that many Microsoft products have went through as they were absorbed into Outlook. Lastly, they clarify that this series will cover Outlook on the Web.
episodes.title: Introduction to Outlook on the Web
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:05.536 --> 00:00:06.660
[MUSIC]
Greetings everyone.

2
00:00:06.660 --> 00:00:09.347
Welcome to another exciting
episode of OfficePro TV.

3
00:00:09.347 --> 00:00:12.566
I'm your host Justin Dennison and
in today's episode,

4
00:00:12.566 --> 00:00:17.260
we're getting started with Outlook on the
Web and that may be a little confusing for

5

you, but no worries,
we have the meister of Outlook.

6
00:00:20.440 --> 00:00:21.340
And that's Miss Vonne Smith.

7
00:00:21.340 --> 00:00:22.355
How are you doing today, Vonne?

8
00:00:22.355 --> 00:00:25.420
>> I'm doing great, and
you definitely hit the nail on the head.

9
00:00:25.420 --> 00:00:29.490
Microsoft can be a little confusing
sometimes with how they label things and

10

really kind of use the same name for

11
00:00:32.490 --> 00:00:33.770

12

So I have a lovely PowerPoint presentation
ready for us to go through all

13

web and really just Outlook in general.

14
00:00:43.830 --> 00:00:45.120
So let's start here.

15
00:00:45.120 --> 00:00:47.250
Do you remember your day planner, Justin?

16
00:00:47.250 --> 00:00:48.360
Did you have one of those?

17
00:00:48.360 --> 00:00:50.205
>> Well, Vonne, no.

18
00:00:50.205 --> 00:00:52.830
>> [LAUGH]
>> I was a horrible planner,

19
00:00:52.830 --> 00:00:54.420
>> prepper kind of individual, so

20
00:00:54.420 --> 00:00:56.580
I was like day planner, throw that away.

21
00:00:56.580 --> 00:00:58.175
I'm sorry, I was a horrible example.

22
00:00:58.175 --> 00:01:00.470
[LAUGH]
>> Well actually Justin,

23
00:01:00.470 --> 00:01:02.835
I don't think I had one either.

24
00:01:02.835 --> 00:01:04.600
[LAUGH]
>> But I do remember then,

25
00:01:04.600 --> 00:01:07.770
I know that a lot of people would
>> take them with them,

26
00:01:07.770 --> 00:01:09.360
and it was their thing.

27
00:01:09.360 --> 00:01:12.890
They had to have their day planner for
whatever they were doing,

28
00:01:12.890 --> 00:01:14.650
because it kept you organized.

29
00:01:14.650 --> 00:01:17.920
It had things like your address book,
ooh, that's the wrong way,

30
00:01:17.920 --> 00:01:19.300
how about we go the other way.

31
00:01:19.300 --> 00:01:19.835
There we go.

32
00:01:19.835 --> 00:01:23.250
[LAUGH] Learn the keyboard
>> to move your Power Point presentation.

33
00:01:23.250 --> 00:01:25.060
So let's go down a slide.

34
00:01:25.060 --> 00:01:27.990
And remember things like
your address book, and

35
00:01:27.990 --> 00:01:32.010
you had maybe like a to-do list in there,
maybe you carried some stamps around there

36
00:01:32.010 --> 00:01:35.240
to have some envelopes to be able
to go ahead and mail some things.

37
00:01:35.240 --> 00:01:37.711
Do you remember that Rolodex there?

38
00:01:37.711 --> 00:01:38.780
Man, Roladexes.

39
00:01:38.780 --> 00:01:43.340
All I know is I just like to spin them
really fast and see all the cards fly out.

40
00:01:43.340 --> 00:01:47.460
I didn't really know what they were for
at that point in time.

41
00:01:47.460 --> 00:01:50.360
>> I remember doing that at
my parent's business, and

42
00:01:50.360 --> 00:01:55.090
my mom would get really mad at me because
I would pull the cards out and all that.

43
00:01:55.090 --> 00:01:57.010
And one with slider, remember the slider?

44
00:01:57.010 --> 00:01:58.010
>> Yeah, those were cool.

45
00:01:58.010 --> 00:01:59.890
>> Yeah, with the metal one,
you pop it up, yeah.

46
00:01:59.890 --> 00:02:01.710
That was at my aunt's house.

47
00:02:01.710 --> 00:02:03.224
She didn't like that one so.

48
00:02:03.224 --> 00:02:07.455
[LAUGH] But all of these different things
were the reason why people went ahead and

49
00:02:07.455 --> 00:02:11.010
carried your day planner around,
because it kept you organized.

50
00:02:11.010 --> 00:02:12.390
Who do I need to contact?

51
00:02:12.390 --> 00:02:13.770
What do I need to do today?

52
00:02:13.770 --> 00:02:15.820
Who do I need to send a letter to?

53
00:02:15.820 --> 00:02:18.990
Well, that really is Outlook.

54
00:02:18.990 --> 00:02:21.780
Okay, so
Outlook is your digital day planner.

55
00:02:21.780 --> 00:02:23.490
It's where you do your email and

56
00:02:23.490 --> 00:02:27.690
that's probably a lot of people,
maybe in a collective knowledge,

57
00:02:27.690 --> 00:02:32.440
associate Outlook with the emailing,
and that's exactly true.

58
00:02:32.440 --> 00:02:37.720
Because that's what you do, and that's
what you use to go ahead and email people.

59
00:02:37.720 --> 00:02:39.610
It also stores all your contacts.

60
00:02:39.610 --> 00:02:40.880
You can have to-do lists.

61
00:02:40.880 --> 00:02:41.590
You have tasks.

62
00:02:41.590 --> 00:02:43.910
You have calendars,
the all important calendar and

63
00:02:43.910 --> 00:02:47.120

00:16:03.295 --> 00:16:04.911
And your account information.

288
00:16:04.911 --> 00:16:10.086
And a lot of times there's that X, but
the other thing is if you don't see the X,

289
00:16:10.086 --> 00:16:14.920
if you click the button again,
it kinda swooshes it again, swoosh.

290
00:16:14.920 --> 00:16:16.909
>> That is a really good word,
Vonne I'm gonna start using that.

291
00:16:16.909 --> 00:16:18.838
>> [LAUGH]
>> Click that button and

292
00:16:18.838 --> 00:16:19.865
it'll swish it away.

293
00:16:19.865 --> 00:16:21.320
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I'm gonna file that

294
00:16:21.320 --> 00:16:22.020
away for later use.

295
00:16:22.020 --> 00:16:24.750
>> It's funny you said swish and
I said swoosh.

296
00:16:24.750 --> 00:16:29.552
>> Who knows, with my accent,
who knows what I said so.

297
00:16:29.552 --> 00:16:30.315
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

298
00:16:30.315 --> 00:16:32.030
>> I would say one of the two, Vonne.

299
00:16:32.030 --> 00:16:35.005
>> Okay,and the letters are right
next to each other on the keyboard.

300
00:16:35.005 --> 00:16:36.795
So you're typing it in your brain, right?

301
00:16:36.795 --> 00:16:37.837
>> Exactly.
>> There you go.

302
00:16:37.837 --> 00:16:43.495
[LAUGH] So coming back over here to the
left-hand side, this is our folder pane.

303
00:16:43.495 --> 00:16:46.565
Depending on which area
of Outlook we're in,

304
00:16:46.565 --> 00:16:51.410
whether we're in our People or
our Calendar or

305
00:16:51.410 --> 00:16:56.128
our Mail, you can see that that
left-hand folder pane is gonna change.

306
00:16:56.128 --> 00:17:01.850
Because that's gonna show you the basic
navigation of that particular area and

307
00:17:01.850 --> 00:17:03.600
your different folders.

308
00:17:03.600 --> 00:17:07.540
And whether you're looking at calendars or
mail, or in this instance, I'm back

309
00:17:07.540 --> 00:17:12.490
in my mail in my inbox versus my deleted
items versus my conversation history.

310
00:17:12.490 --> 00:17:13.700
And things like that.

311
00:17:14.760 --> 00:17:17.945
Since we're talking about the overall
interface, we're not gonna get

312
00:17:17.945 --> 00:17:22.300
too deep into this mail interface,
cuz we have our own episode on that.

313
00:17:23.350 --> 00:17:28.060
Back up at the top on this left-hand side,
we have Search, Mail, and People.

314
00:17:28.060 --> 00:17:30.950
Searching is always a very
good thing to do because hey,

315
00:17:30.950 --> 00:17:35.000
I know we talked about lunch,
but was that an email?

316
00:17:35.000 --> 00:17:37.060
Was that a calendar item?

317
00:17:37.060 --> 00:17:38.370
I don't remember which one.

318
00:17:39.430 --> 00:17:40.920
Do take notice before I go ahead and

319
00:17:40.920 --> 00:17:45.410
start typing, if I'm in the Calendar
section, I'm searching my calendar.

320
00:17:45.410 --> 00:17:47.940
If I'm in People, I'm searching people.

321
00:17:47.940 --> 00:17:53.780
So the search does get, we'll call it
filtered, to whatever area you are in.

322
00:17:53.780 --> 00:17:57.695
But if you trying to do a search
across all of the different areas,

323
00:17:57.695 --> 00:18:02.530
if you go to the Mail section and
you type in, let's say lunch.

324
00:18:03.720 --> 00:18:07.040
And I hit Enter, now notice it says,
search People, searching Groups.

325
00:18:07.040 --> 00:18:10.350
If I hit Enter,
it brings my folder pane, or

326
00:18:10.350 --> 00:18:15.230
that left-hand side,
we'll just call it, into my search.

327
00:18:15.230 --> 00:18:19.090
And so it's giving me different
things here of all folders versus no,

328
00:18:19.090 --> 00:18:22.260
just stick with the Inbox, or
just stick with the Sent Items.

329
00:18:22.260 --> 00:18:27.050
And notice I have over here,
I have an email, I also have a calendar,

330
00:18:27.050 --> 00:18:28.350
I have some other things.

331
00:18:28.350 --> 00:18:32.860
So you might need to try to stay in that
one area to try and get an overall search,

332
00:18:32.860 --> 00:18:38.142
rather than getting more specific in the
different areas that you need to be in.

333
00:18:38.142 --> 00:18:42.160
Notice that you do have some
other types of filterings and

334
00:18:42.160 --> 00:18:45.060
search parameters when you
start going into your search.

335
00:18:45.060 --> 00:18:46.965
But now it's like okay,
I'm done with my search.

336
00:18:46.965 --> 00:18:51.893
It's nice that I put right there at
the top, Exit Search, you come back into

337
00:18:51.893 --> 00:18:56.360
here and you're back into where ever
you had left off on in your mail.

338
00:18:57.860 --> 00:19:01.320
Next to the search area, across the top,

339
00:19:01.320 --> 00:19:06.420
this main section up here,
I'm gonna call that the top menu bar.

340
00:19:06.420 --> 00:19:07.681
That's what I'm calling it.

341
00:19:07.681 --> 00:19:11.711
[LAUGH] Because it is going to give you
different options that come up depending

342
00:19:11.711 --> 00:19:13.190
on what you are on.

343
00:19:13.190 --> 00:19:17.760
Right now it just says New,
cuz I'm in the inbox area of my mail.

344
00:19:17.760 --> 00:19:21.700
So if I have a drop down, normally I'm
gonna probably start a new message.

345
00:19:21.700 --> 00:19:25.510
But I do have a different option of
doing a calendar event or a group.

346
00:19:25.510 --> 00:19:31.360
But if I select a specific email, notice
how my menu bar, my top navigation area,

347
00:19:31.360 --> 00:19:35.680
it changes to say, well now you're
actually in a specific message.

348
00:19:35.680 --> 00:19:37.440
What do you wanna do with that message?

349
00:19:37.440 --> 00:19:38.570
Do you want to move it?

350
00:19:38.570 --> 00:19:39.490
Do you wanna categorize it?

351
00:19:39.490 --> 00:19:41.040
Do you wanna delete it?

352
00:19:41.040 --> 00:19:45.420
If I was back over in my Calendar,
notice that it's says Adding Calendars.

353
00:19:45.420 --> 00:19:48.920
Interesting calendars, and
that's were you could actually pull up

354
00:19:48.920 --> 00:19:53.410
different calendars that are tied to your
favorite sports team or different things.

355
00:19:53.410 --> 00:19:57.020
It's kind of a cute little
feature that it allows you to do.

356
00:19:57.020 --> 00:20:01.828
And of course I'm following my
favorite hockey team, go Lightning.

357
00:20:01.828 --> 00:20:02.754
So [LAUGH] you could go ahead and
do things like that.

358
00:20:02.754 --> 00:20:07.182
Back into that search again,
notice, or sorry, the settings,

359
00:20:07.182 --> 00:20:12.075
since I'm here in Calendar, it is
giving me calendar appearance settings.

360
00:20:12.075 --> 00:20:16.888
Versus back in the Mail, the settings
are gonna talk about things like automatic

361
00:20:16.888 --> 00:20:19.260
replies and display settings.

362
00:20:19.260 --> 00:20:25.646
So it does take you to specific areas of
those settings that are in that area.

363
00:20:25.646 --> 00:20:28.929
And actually it's behind my head,
so if you go ahead, and

364
00:20:28.929 --> 00:20:30.950
let me show you behind me.

365
00:20:30.950 --> 00:20:35.670
We've got, down here, your app settings,
at the very bottom, I did have to scroll.

366
00:20:35.670 --> 00:20:38.450
Maybe I'm in the Mail section, but

367
00:20:38.450 --> 00:20:41.260
I wanted to change some
of my calendar settings.

368
00:20:41.260 --> 00:20:45.186
It goes right over here, it doesn't
matter which one you click on it.

369
00:20:45.186 --> 00:20:49.346
Cuz when you click on it,
notice over on the left-hand side,

370
00:20:49.346 --> 00:20:52.070
you're getting to all of the settings.

371
00:20:52.070 --> 00:20:54.178
It's kind of like if your
on the desktop version,

372
00:20:54.178 --> 00:20:58.350
you're going to that File tab or the
backstage view, and going to Options and

373
00:20:58.350 --> 00:21:01.710
then getting that dialog box that
has all the different pieces.

374
00:21:01.710 --> 00:21:08.170
This is where you find it, and so it's
there, you have to kind of dig for it.

375
00:21:08.170 --> 00:21:11.340
Now since I've been to it so
many times, it's just second nature.

376
00:21:11.340 --> 00:21:16.430
But it took me a while to find that
at first, where is my out of office?

377
00:21:16.430 --> 00:21:22.240
Where is where I can change how
what's been read in my message box?

378
00:21:22.240 --> 00:21:23.539
All of it's in here in your Settings.

379
00:21:24.540 --> 00:21:27.850
If you come into the General,
you have your things like your account.

380
00:21:27.850 --> 00:21:30.080
You could go ahead and
manage the lite version.

381
00:21:30.080 --> 00:21:35.840
We did mention Outlook Lite in our talking
about setting up our email account.

382
00:21:35.840 --> 00:21:38.462
So that's where you could go ahead and
change that.

383
00:21:38.462 --> 00:21:42.290
You could change your theme, but that's
always over on the right-hand side too.

384
00:21:42.290 --> 00:21:46.840
And then you go into your different
areas of My Mail Settings.

385
00:21:46.840 --> 00:21:49.950
How do I change my junk mail reporting?

386
00:21:49.950 --> 00:21:52.030
How do I do my mark as read?

387
00:21:52.030 --> 00:21:55.769
My retention policy, now this is something
that you might not have access to,

388
00:21:55.769 --> 00:21:59.521
depending on your level of subscription,
so don't worry if it's not there.

389
00:21:59.521 --> 00:22:03.040
Connected accounts, we talked about
that in the set up email accounts.

390
00:22:03.040 --> 00:22:04.480
Maybe you wanna manage your Gmail or

391
00:22:04.480 --> 00:22:08.370
other types of email accounts here,
you could add them.

392
00:22:08.370 --> 00:22:13.590
So you could see here, any type of area
that I wanna control the settings,

393
00:22:13.590 --> 00:22:17.970
I just go down to that bottom
right-hand side, get into the area.

394
00:22:17.970 --> 00:22:22.650
My left-hand side navigation pane
brings up all the information that

395
00:22:22.650 --> 00:22:27.040
I need to go ahead and access, and
that's where you control everything.

396
00:22:27.040 --> 00:22:32.954
One small note, everything, like I said,
is pretty much the same in Outlook.com.

397
00:22:32.954 --> 00:22:35.013
The biggest difference
is that your settings,

398
00:22:35.013 --> 00:22:36.770
it just shows as a little drop down menu.

399
00:22:36.770 --> 00:22:40.990
It doesn't show over as a navigation
pane like the other ones.

400
00:22:40.990 --> 00:22:44.230
But if I go into Options,

401
00:22:44.230 --> 00:22:47.388
it gives me all the same things over
there on that left-hand side as well.

402
00:22:47.388 --> 00:22:51.540
So you could go into the General,
in the Mail, in the Calendar, and

403
00:22:51.540 --> 00:22:53.920
go through things like that.

404
00:22:53.920 --> 00:22:57.385
So just know that where you're
clicking on makes a big difference.

405
00:22:57.385 --> 00:23:01.340
Being very aware of your tabs,
what panes are coming up.

406
00:23:01.340 --> 00:23:03.330
Do I need to go to the left,
do I need to go to the right?

407
00:23:03.330 --> 00:23:07.430
It takes a while to find the measuring
cups and find the flour and

408
00:23:07.430 --> 00:23:09.790
find your bowl and make those brownies.

409
00:23:09.790 --> 00:23:14.485
But you'll be able to start baking
to your heart's content very soon.

410
00:23:14.485 --> 00:23:17.375
>> Well Vonne, just to continue on
with that analogy, just remember,

411
00:23:17.375 --> 00:23:20.015
if you're in the bedroom, you're probably
not gonna find your baking goods like you

412
00:23:20.015 --> 00:23:21.595
anticipated, so always-
>> [LAUGH]

413
00:23:21.595 --> 00:23:23.235
>> Always be aware of where you are within

414
00:23:23.235 --> 00:23:23.885
the application.

415
00:23:23.885 --> 00:23:28.075
Now I didn't know that the Outlook
premium model had as many features, and

416
00:23:28.075 --> 00:23:30.375
it's pretty full-fledged
to be a web application.

417
00:23:30.375 --> 00:23:31.975
So if you've always thought,

418
00:23:31.975 --> 00:23:35.150
it's kind of a watered down version of
the install, it's not what I'm seeing.

419
00:23:35.150 --> 00:23:38.170
And I know we have a lot more to do.

420
00:23:38.170 --> 00:23:41.540
So definitely join us back as
we continue Outlook on the Web..

421
00:23:41.540 --> 00:23:44.900
But, for now, signing off for OfficeProTV,
I've been your host Justin Dennison.

422
00:23:44.900 --> 00:23:45.560
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

423
00:23:45.560 --> 00:23:47.969
>> And we'll see you next time.

424
00:23:47.969 --> 00:23:51.329
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore the mail interface portion of Outlook. Specifically, they identify folders, peruse default views, and tweak a few settings.
episodes.title: Mail Interface
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.499
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.499 --> 00:00:09.220
Greetings everyone and welcome to
another exciting episode of OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:09.220 --> 00:00:10.710
I'm your host Justin Dennison and

4
00:00:10.710 --> 00:00:13.150
in today's episode well we're
back at you with more Outlook.

5
00:00:13.150 --> 00:00:15.210
You asked for it, we got more of it and

6
00:00:15.210 --> 00:00:17.800
in particular well we're gonna
look at the mail interfacing.

7
00:00:17.800 --> 00:00:20.180
And to help us do that
is Miss Vonne Smith.

8
00:00:20.180 --> 00:00:21.220
How you doing today Vonne?

9
00:00:21.220 --> 00:00:21.860
>> I'm good.

10
00:00:21.860 --> 00:00:27.150
Yes, we are going to explore the interface
specifically in the mail section

11
00:00:27.150 --> 00:00:31.850
of our Outlook on the web or
our Outlook Web application.

12
00:00:31.850 --> 00:00:33.938
So let's jump right in and get started.

13
00:00:33.938 --> 00:00:37.860
I've got Joey's email
pulled up right here and

14
00:00:37.860 --> 00:00:42.280
we're in the mail section and so
let's talk about these different areas.

15
00:00:42.280 --> 00:00:44.770
We did talk about the Outlook interface

16
00:00:44.770 --> 00:00:48.370
altogether of where the calendar
is in these different places.

17
00:00:48.370 --> 00:00:55.720
Now let's talk about these folders
within our email, I almost said system.

18
00:00:57.060 --> 00:00:58.670
Just throwing out words here.

19
00:00:58.670 --> 00:01:01.950
They're technically called folders.

20
00:01:01.950 --> 00:01:06.770
What type of folders do we have
that are working with our mail?

21
00:01:06.770 --> 00:01:12.640
We have our inbox inmail that's
coming into us that we are receiving.

22
00:01:13.720 --> 00:01:15.320
There's a couple of different icons and

23
00:01:15.320 --> 00:01:17.020
things that as we move
around through here,

24
00:01:17.020 --> 00:01:20.940
whether you hover over them, there's some
things with some numbers to the right.

25
00:01:20.940 --> 00:01:23.590
There's these little
carrot looking things,

26
00:01:23.590 --> 00:01:25.560
at least that's what I'm calling them.

27
00:01:25.560 --> 00:01:29.670
You can call them collapse expand buttons,
they're little arrows but

28
00:01:29.670 --> 00:01:34.660
they look like carrots to me so-
>> I would also typify that as a carrot.

29
00:01:34.660 --> 00:01:36.620
I'd say carrots for the little up and

30
00:01:36.620 --> 00:01:40.400
down arrows so yeah,
I'm gonna go with it, we'll go with it.

31
00:01:40.400 --> 00:01:43.350
>> And I don't know if it's like a coding
thing or just a keyboard thing or it's,

32
00:01:43.350 --> 00:01:44.510
you know what?

33
00:01:44.510 --> 00:01:49.043
You can name it anything you want, but
it's those little icons to the right,

34
00:01:49.043 --> 00:01:52.710
that would be the other right
[LAUGH] of some of these folders.

35
00:01:52.710 --> 00:01:55.620
So there it just means that
there's more things to it.

36
00:01:55.620 --> 00:01:59.000
Also known as what I'm
starting to hover over things

37
00:01:59.000 --> 00:02:03.190
especially over here on the left hand side
there's this little stars that come up

38
00:02:03.190 --> 00:02:07.170
cuz that has to indicate with what's
over here which are favorites.

39
00:02:07.170 --> 00:02:10.950
We think about I think a lot of times
you actually have it right up here,

40
00:02:10.950 --> 00:02:14.940
the star on your address bar
to add to your favorites.

41
00:02:14.940 --> 00:02:18.130
So it's nice they're keeping with
the same theme going with stars

42
00:02:18.130 --> 00:02:21.450
because over on our left
hand file navigation pane,

43
00:02:21.450 --> 00:02:26.250
you can see that we have things that
you could mark as your favorites.

44
00:02:26.250 --> 00:02:29.070
Right now, the only thing that's
in our favorites is our inbox.

45
00:02:29.070 --> 00:02:34.185
But maybe there are specific folders that
you've created cuz you can create your

46
00:02:34.185 --> 00:02:39.625
own custom folders for organization cuz,
we keep calling these folders and

47
00:02:39.625 --> 00:02:43.115
they are and I always equate it
back to well you have a desk.

48
00:02:43.115 --> 00:02:46.350
Like a physical desk that you sit at and
you have a drawer and

49
00:02:46.350 --> 00:02:50.600
you have file folders, and
they are compartmentalized into

50
00:02:50.600 --> 00:02:54.090
different things that, these are the taxes
for this year, taxes for another year.

51
00:02:54.090 --> 00:02:56.130
Cuz that's pretty much the only
thing I keep in my file folder.

52
00:02:56.130 --> 00:02:59.150
>> I was going along with you there
Vonne until your brought up taxes, and

53
00:02:59.150 --> 00:03:00.315
then I kinda got sad.

54
00:03:00.315 --> 00:03:03.270
>> [LAUGH]
>> But yeah we tend to,

55
00:03:03.270 --> 00:03:07.510
whatever we do we divide them up in the
logical units that make sense to us and

56
00:03:07.510 --> 00:03:08.890
that's what these are reflecting.

57
00:03:08.890 --> 00:03:12.960
They're not necessarily physical folders
that you would see like on your desktop or

58
00:03:12.960 --> 00:03:15.590
something because well,
how would you add to [INAUDIBLE].

59
00:03:15.590 --> 00:03:18.330
It's kind of I would add
folders inside of folders and

60
00:03:18.330 --> 00:03:21.346
if you haven't truly have that
happen you may have some fun times.

61
00:03:21.346 --> 00:03:23.570
>> [LAUGH]
>> You can just click for days.

62
00:03:23.570 --> 00:03:24.425
>> Yeah.

63
00:03:24.425 --> 00:03:25.900
[LAUGH]
>> But it is a logical

64
00:03:25.900 --> 00:03:27.140
organizational thing.

65
00:03:27.140 --> 00:03:31.000
>> And we can make our own folders to
put things in and that's where for

66
00:03:31.000 --> 00:03:32.340
example, my inbox,

67
00:03:32.340 --> 00:03:36.030
you might be looking at yours like I
don't have that carrot thing to the left.

68
00:03:36.030 --> 00:03:36.938
Why do you have it?

69
00:03:36.938 --> 00:03:38.920
Because if I click on it,

70
00:03:38.920 --> 00:03:44.060
it's actually expanding out to show you
that I have created my own folders.

71
00:03:44.060 --> 00:03:48.070
In here for me to organize myself,
because I could say hey,

72
00:03:48.070 --> 00:03:53.030
any messages that's coming in from JT,
I wanna put them in JT folder that's

73
00:03:53.030 --> 00:03:56.510
inside of the inbox folder and
I could, like Justin was saying,

74
00:03:56.510 --> 00:04:00.480
I could put folders inside of
folders to keep myself organized.

75
00:04:00.480 --> 00:04:01.750
Whatever floats your boat,

76
00:04:01.750 --> 00:04:06.330
whatever makes your life easier
>> Some people like to like super

77
00:04:06.330 --> 00:04:10.190
organized, micro-level, some people just
keep everything in the same place and

78
00:04:10.190 --> 00:04:13.100
have naming conventions or
their own kind of system.

79
00:04:13.100 --> 00:04:15.510
Your system, your rules, that's fine.

80
00:04:15.510 --> 00:04:20.860
Just go ahead and make sure that Outlook
matches that and it's working for you and

81
00:04:20.860 --> 00:04:24.770
not against you, and then sometimes it can
start to work against us a little bit.

82
00:04:24.770 --> 00:04:27.520
But that's why I have
these carrot things and

83
00:04:27.520 --> 00:04:31.011
the different names next to

I could show it as a focused inbox or not.

00:17:07.412 --> 00:17:13.140
And if I change this to messages,
I personally, I prefer conversations.

308
00:17:13.140 --> 00:17:17.310
I like to kinda keep everything together

June online,
each one comes in individually.

And you might have 4 or 5, 14,
20 emails going back and forth.

311
00:17:25.640 --> 00:17:27.930
I personally like conversations better.

312
00:17:27.930 --> 00:17:32.140
So I'm gonna just put that back, but
I did wanna show you that is quite easy

00:17:32.140 --> 00:17:35.250
to make it kinda go back and
forth from that.

314
00:17:36.996 --> 00:17:38.724
Well now I can't show it as conversations.

That's okay because if you can't find it

00:17:47.310 --> 00:17:52.240

318
00:17:52.240 --> 00:17:57.160
And I can turn off the focused inbox and

00:17:57.160 --> 00:18:00.560
It's just all of my mail

00:18:00.560 --> 00:18:03.490
I still have my junk mail,

00:18:03.490 --> 00:18:08.080
But they're not separating it out

00:18:08.080 --> 00:18:10.350
you can always change that.

00:18:11.400 --> 00:18:14.540
In these mails, the message list,

you do have a lot of icons that

00:18:30.080 --> 00:18:32.290

It will let me know if I

333
00:18:38.300 --> 00:18:39.020
I replied.

00:18:39.020 --> 00:18:40.390

00:18:40.390 --> 00:18:45.430
And, this is my little Info bar that

00:18:45.430 --> 00:18:49.120

00:18:53.180 --> 00:18:56.280

00:18:59.140 --> 00:19:01.245

00:19:01.245 --> 00:19:02.740

00:19:02.740 --> 00:19:05.250
When I hover over my messages,

00:19:05.250 --> 00:19:08.930

00:19:08.930 --> 00:19:11.500
Do I want to mark as unread?

00:19:11.500 --> 00:19:14.560

00:19:14.560 --> 00:19:17.780
to let me know what this is,
whether I can flag it or

00:19:17.780 --> 00:19:23.310
I can pin this different places of how
I can start helping me organize myself.

348
00:19:23.310 --> 00:19:27.286
So there's a lot of different icons
that come up, like that is a calendar.

349
00:19:27.286 --> 00:19:30.970
I need to stop doing the hovering when I'm

350
00:19:30.970 --> 00:19:34.620
This is a calendar request and
so on and so forth.

00:19:34.620 --> 00:19:38.580
Lots of different icons, some have

00:19:38.580 --> 00:19:39.790

00:19:39.790 --> 00:19:44.670
So we'll be going through all of these

00:19:44.670 --> 00:19:50.170

00:19:50.170 --> 00:19:51.920
But wanted to point those out.

00:19:53.110 --> 00:19:58.300
Notice as we pointed out in the Outlook
interface, your top menu bars or

00:19:58.300 --> 00:20:01.610
columns, or navigation bar,
will give you different options,

00:20:01.610 --> 00:20:02.950
depending on what you're clicking on.

00:20:02.950 --> 00:20:04.780
So you click on a message, and

00:20:04.780 --> 00:20:08.410

You also get this little dot dot dot your,
ellipses, off the top, that's not the top,

00:20:13.000 --> 00:20:14.090
that's the right.

00:20:14.090 --> 00:20:20.860
And it will give even more options
that you can do with your messages.

00:20:20.860 --> 00:20:23.810
Quick little side note

00:20:23.810 --> 00:20:28.410
whether it's a message,
a folder in your folder pane.

00:20:28.410 --> 00:20:32.803
A lot of times right clicking will give
you that same option which is sometimes

weird when you're web interface cuz when
you're web interface a lot of times if

00:20:36.620 --> 00:20:39.725
you're right clicking you're only
just gonna get like open a new tab.

00:20:39.725 --> 00:20:44.510
Or the different things that come up by
default when you're in a browser, but

00:20:44.510 --> 00:20:49.220
specifically in this web application
right clicking in this area will

00:20:49.220 --> 00:20:51.040
give you some different options.

00:20:51.040 --> 00:20:58.060
So definitely check that out as well,

00:20:58.060 --> 00:21:01.090
Maybe you don't want
the reading pane to come up.

00:21:01.090 --> 00:21:05.225
Maybe you want something
else to do be different.

00:21:05.225 --> 00:21:08.468
[LAUGH] Cuz I can't remember what I've,

00:21:08.468 --> 00:21:11.560
I'm pretty sure it was-
>> The conversations instead of individual

messages.

00:21:12.076 --> 00:21:16.620
And I tend to like conversation as well

00:21:16.620 --> 00:21:19.390
over a series of time, over a time span.

00:21:19.390 --> 00:21:23.810
And if it says messages, well I'm gonna

And if there's a difference of two

well the last one and
the first one may be distinctly apart.

00:21:32.090 --> 00:21:36.160
But if I group them by conversations,
then it's based on the most recent one,

00:21:36.160 --> 00:21:37.640
and they're grouped together.

385
00:21:37.640 --> 00:21:41.450
So replies are nice, but
how do we get that back?

00:21:41.450 --> 00:21:42.435
I want that back.

00:21:42.435 --> 00:21:45.200
>> Yes, and I'm so glad you're here to
keep me on point, because I'm like,

I know I mentioned two things specifically

00:21:48.820 --> 00:21:50.810
So yes, focused inbox,

00:21:50.810 --> 00:21:55.940
let's get into our mail settings by coming
over here to our little wheelie guy.

00:21:55.940 --> 00:21:58.060
And you come into our display settings.

If you don't like display settings,

But, let's go to Display settings and hit

have the most commonly used

00:22:14.120 --> 00:22:15.090
Reading pane, perfect.

00:22:15.090 --> 00:22:19.900
So that's where I could hide the reading

00:22:19.900 --> 00:22:22.501
And notice it does say

00:22:22.501 --> 00:22:27.460

our sent items, our draft items.

So those are different options that

Maybe I don't want to have

Those are the ones where

the first line of that email to

00:23:00.697 --> 00:23:03.490
Display settings,

00:23:03.490 --> 00:23:08.470
Okay, now this one it's like, okay, well

00:23:08.470 --> 00:23:09.630

Just a couple quick more, a few more

And in the layout that is

There's our focused inbox, so

So there's that one.

The same thing that I was talking about

another way you could get to it, and how

Outlook to work for you.

Lots of lots of settings.

453
00:25:19.253 --> 00:25:22.200
>> Well I'll tell ya,

I was unprepared for

00:25:26.830 --> 00:25:28.240
And honestly I'm gonna tell you,

00:25:34.110 --> 00:25:35.120
I want that.

00:25:43.881 --> 00:25:45.370

00:25:46.200 --> 00:25:47.769

00:25:47.769 --> 00:25:53.751

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore the basics of emailing. Specifically in this episode, creating and receiving email with a single recipient and how to attach files.
episodes.title: Mail Basics
episodes.transcript:

[MUSIC]

00:00:09.340 --> 00:00:10.610

00:00:24.930 --> 00:00:26.389

I'm ready for all the shenanigans.

00:00:26.389 --> 00:00:26.978
[LAUGH].

>> Yes, I do love a good shenanigans.

00:00:31.318 --> 00:00:35.820

So there's really not much difference.

There's a few things that might

I know in one thing in the Outlook.com,

I thought that was one of the cutest

I was like so

And like hey,
this is not coming from the same person.

So when we get into that button

that might be the biggest difference

And then when we start

there's some other things on the storage

Once we get to it,

So we're gonna stay, I'm gonna stay

So, Joey's inbox I actually left this,

I don't have the reading

So I'm just having it in what

00:02:19.940 --> 00:02:22.598
if you're used to looking at
this the desktop version.

00:02:22.598 --> 00:02:25.460
I figured I'd change up
the view a little bit and

00:02:25.460 --> 00:02:28.360
give us a different

What do I wanna do to

I'm in my inbox or

Whether I am in sent mail or

So I clicked on the New button, and

area, I should say in the reading

I said reading pane but I've just

And you can stay in here and

But the two buttons I wanna show you over

You have what looks like two little

00:28:23.745 --> 00:28:27.635
There's also a drop down next to it
to where you could preview this,

509
00:28:27.635 --> 00:28:29.425
I can see what it looks like.

510
00:28:29.425 --> 00:28:32.545
I could upload to OneDrive, hmm well
that's kind of an interesting thing.

511
00:28:32.545 --> 00:28:36.545
So if I wanted to have this here but
it's like but it's my file but

512
00:28:36.545 --> 00:28:38.050
I really want it on my computer.

513
00:28:38.050 --> 00:28:40.930
Think about it when you receive
attachments you're going to have

514
00:28:40.930 --> 00:28:45.390
some of these same options, so it's pretty
cool that it gives you, it's all seamless.

515
00:28:45.390 --> 00:28:50.100
But in this case since it's already mine,
I don't really need to do that.

516
00:28:50.100 --> 00:28:53.570
But the other one I wanted to point out
was move image to the message body.

517
00:28:53.570 --> 00:28:55.740
Instead of saving it as an attachment,

518
00:28:55.740 --> 00:28:59.330
or sending it as an attachment,
you put it in line with the message.

519
00:29:00.760 --> 00:29:02.940
It's personal preference but

520
00:29:02.940 --> 00:29:06.500
if it's in the message it's
more of a formatting thing.

521
00:29:06.500 --> 00:29:08.930
If it's in an attachment,
I know that that's to me.

522
00:29:08.930 --> 00:29:11.880
I want to give you this file.

523
00:29:11.880 --> 00:29:16.370
So I'd probably stick
with keeping it as is but

524
00:29:16.370 --> 00:29:21.290
I wanted to at least explore some of
those options with you before we go.

525
00:29:21.290 --> 00:29:27.320
Let me go ahead and send this off to
Justin that he gets a picture of Joey and

526
00:29:27.320 --> 00:29:31.820
that is just some of the basic things
you can do with composing an email.

527
00:29:31.820 --> 00:29:33.320
Addressing it to somebody.

528
00:29:33.320 --> 00:29:37.580
Receiving the emails, responding to it and
how to add an attachment.

529
00:29:37.580 --> 00:29:41.190
>> Well Von it definitely seems really
easy when you list them off like that but

530
00:29:41.190 --> 00:29:44.425
it's actually a lot more complicated
when you actually dive in.

531
00:29:44.425 --> 00:29:48.170
Now I know we have a lot more to do
with composing and managing emails so

532
00:29:48.170 --> 00:29:50.350
we're gonna have to come
back with some more parts.

533
00:29:50.350 --> 00:29:54.280
So continue with us, but we're gonna
go ahead and sign off for OFFICEPRO.TV.

534
00:29:54.280 --> 00:29:55.830
I've been your host Justin Dennison.

535
00:29:55.830 --> 00:29:56.640
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

536
00:29:56.640 --> 00:30:00.380
>> We'll see you next time.

537
00:30:00.380 --> 00:30:03.240
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore the basics of emailing. Specifically in this episode, Vonne demonstrates the usage of the CC field, the BCC field, using the drafts, and forwarding messages.
episodes.title: Mail Basics Part 2

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:05.430
[MUSIC]

>> I'm good.

13
00:00:27.989 --> 00:00:29.729
[LAUGH]

[LAUGH] So in part one we talked about

00:00:36.100 --> 00:00:38.850
And now we're gonna be dealing

00:00:38.850 --> 00:00:43.021
And we're gonna talk about that wonderful
BCC field, and we're gonna talk

about being blindsided and talk about the

Why don't we just go ahead and
jump right in to Joey's account, and

we're on our Inbox and we're ready to go.

So there's a lot of times where you need

00:00:59.810 --> 00:01:03.029

different than a group here in Outlook

00:01:08.608 --> 00:01:13.659
And so I need to address say hey,

So give me some money, so I can go buy

Why don't we start a new message and

The cc,
now the cc field is carbon copy, and

this is the place where I

Now let me tell you a little

00:02:01.540 --> 00:02:04.150
So I will see that it is addressed to me,

but there are six people

00:02:07.640 --> 00:02:10.934

00:02:10.934 --> 00:02:12.319
And it's like, okay so are you,

The boss is in on this, so it's out there.

It's like this is public record.

Everybody is all knowing that

51

[LAUGH]
>> So

if you're directly addressing

like you're speaking to a group,

54
00:03:12.092 --> 00:03:15.300
But you're talk about the cc game,

however sometimes I think of it

00:03:18.640 --> 00:03:20.808
It's the, or the eavesdrop button.

57
00:03:20.808 --> 00:03:24.951

>> You're like giving a direct line

You're like here,
hold this I'm gonna talk to them.

00:03:28.630 --> 00:03:30.800

So be aware that the CC, those people

And it's kinda weird, because how

You're just listening in,

Hopefully that never happens

66

To though, you're broadcasting the message

00:03:51.597 --> 00:03:52.685
anybody in the To field.

68
00:03:52.685 --> 00:03:55.790
It's a little semantic difference,
but it's important.

69
00:03:55.790 --> 00:03:58.150
Especially in email etiquette in the sort.

70

>> Yeah,
I totally hear what you're saying.

And I love the game where there's

So it's like, hey, I know that you're

I have to go ahead and

So this might be a little,

looking at who is in

So I'm going to address

And this is where I'm directly going

Quick point here, and

I typed Lance's email in wrong on

00:05:33.910 --> 00:05:35.590

Take notice that it's remembering

00:05:41.018 --> 00:05:42.620
That's not right.

00:05:42.620 --> 00:05:47.820
There's no typos in there, it's just that

00:05:47.820 --> 00:05:52.150
It's Officeprodemoco.onmicrosoft.com.

00:05:52.150 --> 00:05:55.117
So it remembers your wrongs ones too.

[LAUGH] So make sure you watch to get

00:06:02.790 --> 00:06:06.850
I'm going to check on Lance, so

00:06:10.610 --> 00:06:13.020
Those are the three people

Everybody gets their own little bubble,

And then I could go ahead and

Maybe I realize like,

The cool thing is,

>> You have all these assistive

But email clients, sometimes they'll

And part of that is, well, is that

I can tell you,

So I don't want this strict

I think it's format message body, you'll

So multiple recipients,

00:09:12.990 --> 00:09:14.980
I'm just gonna go ahead and

Let's talk about the Bcc field, this is

00:09:23.260 --> 00:09:24.260
What is it?

It stands for Blind Carbon Copy.

00:09:27.050 --> 00:09:29.941
And I'm gonna click it over here

00:09:33.407 --> 00:09:35.734
But I do like it that
it's off to the side and

00:09:35.734 --> 00:09:38.470

167
00:09:38.470 --> 00:09:43.700
The other things that you can do, it might
show up in here for once in a while.

00:09:43.700 --> 00:09:47.210
And there is an option,
actually I don't think it's in here,

I'm crossing two streams.

00:09:48.860 --> 00:09:50.876
You could set in your options, or

your settings to where you always see

And you could, in that same setting, you

00:10:04.050 --> 00:10:06.350
It's like, why would I ever wanna

00:10:06.350 --> 00:10:08.300
the only person it's coming from is me.

175
00:10:08.300 --> 00:10:11.050
Well, if you're managing
multiple email accounts, and

00:10:11.050 --> 00:10:15.410
you want to send an email out from your
account, or your boss's account, or

00:10:15.410 --> 00:10:18.250
maybe your other Gmail or Yahoo account,

178
00:10:18.250 --> 00:10:23.000
then you might wanna make sure you
have that from field showing as well.

179
00:10:23.000 --> 00:10:27.950
So you could go ahead and click on that,
and to let you know where those settings

00:10:27.950 --> 00:10:32.540
are, I just said it's somewhere in here,
I know it's down in the Mail.

00:10:32.540 --> 00:10:37.012
And then I believe you can go into your

182
00:10:37.012 --> 00:10:41.480

00:10:41.480 --> 00:10:46.930
It's in here, [LAUGH] I should have

184
00:10:46.930 --> 00:10:49.570
But it is in here.

185
00:10:49.570 --> 00:10:50.450
>> Actually, if you

00:10:50.450 --> 00:10:52.572
go back to the actual email-
>> There it is.

00:10:52.572 --> 00:10:53.457

188
00:10:53.457 --> 00:10:55.890

00:10:55.890 --> 00:10:57.240
Cuz I'm like, I will find it.

190
00:10:58.530 --> 00:11:01.240
Those are the ones that hey,

00:11:01.240 --> 00:11:03.426
I do this all the time, I know it's

So, this is from Chris and maybe there's
some great information in this email that

410
00:24:00.599 --> 00:24:04.258
I need to pass along to Justin Timberlake,
or Justin Dennison,

411
00:24:04.258 --> 00:24:06.722
whichever Justin I feel like addressing.

412
00:24:06.722 --> 00:24:10.513
But I just wanna take all this,
move it on.

413
00:24:10.513 --> 00:24:14.710
I'm gonna click the little drop down
button, and I'm going to choose Forward.

414
00:24:14.710 --> 00:24:18.450
I want to forward this email
onto another person, and

415
00:24:18.450 --> 00:24:21.820
notice when I do that,
in the subject it puts that Fw.

416
00:24:21.820 --> 00:24:26.290
So that way, the recipient knows, hey,

417
00:24:26.290 --> 00:24:30.210
you're getting a forwarded
email from Joey.

418
00:24:30.210 --> 00:24:36.680
But its the email from Chris that Joey
received, so just moving it on along.

419
00:24:36.680 --> 00:24:43.103
And I can address this to Justin Ford,

420
00:24:43.103 --> 00:24:50.344
and I can say take
a look at Chris's email.

421
00:24:50.344 --> 00:24:55.380
So you can still go ahead and
add whatever information you need in here.

422
00:24:55.380 --> 00:24:59.360
Sometimes I would do this with a lot
of the people that I was working with.

423
00:24:59.360 --> 00:25:03.086
Maybe there was an alert from the IT
department at the university,

424
00:25:03.086 --> 00:25:07.809
I was talking about different changes that
we're gonna be coming up on the network,

425
00:25:07.809 --> 00:25:10.270
hey, just making sure you got this.

426
00:25:10.270 --> 00:25:14.920
Or with any other organization that maybe
they weren't on that distribution list or

427
00:25:14.920 --> 00:25:17.440
that mass email list, so
I'd forward it along to say hey,

428
00:25:17.440 --> 00:25:19.398
make sure you go ahead and check this out.

429
00:25:19.398 --> 00:25:23.645
In the flip-side, you could
always take a forwarded email and

430
00:25:23.645 --> 00:25:27.861
you could get rid of all of this
extra information sometimes.

431
00:25:27.861 --> 00:25:30.390
Like, so I just wanted to show you this,

432
00:25:30.390 --> 00:25:33.483
you don't need to see, cuz I might have
had it forwarded, forwarded, forwarded,

433
00:25:33.483 --> 00:25:38.430
I don't want all the extra in the middle
part, you can delete all that out.

434
00:25:38.430 --> 00:25:43.400
You technically can go ahead and
delete out the Fw: in the subject,

435
00:25:43.400 --> 00:25:46.490
so it doesn't even look
like a forwarded email.

436
00:25:46.490 --> 00:25:48.380
It's just coming from you and

437
00:25:48.380 --> 00:25:51.429
they don't see all of that other
information in the middle of it.

438
00:25:52.930 --> 00:25:58.100
It's still some type of information
that you have control over

439
00:25:58.100 --> 00:26:02.220
to be able to send it
along however you want to.

440
00:26:02.220 --> 00:26:05.590
That is the button where you
know you have forwarded it.

441
00:26:05.590 --> 00:26:09.420
I will go ahead and send this and
now I have forwarded it.

442
00:26:09.420 --> 00:26:14.780
The only other thing I wanted to
address would be printing an email,

443
00:26:14.780 --> 00:26:20.190
if you ever needed to have a hard
physical copy of somebody's email.

444
00:26:20.190 --> 00:26:23.000
I did that double clicking again,
here we go,

445
00:26:23.000 --> 00:26:24.980
that's fine,
we can totally double-click it.

446
00:26:24.980 --> 00:26:26.310
I really wanna double-click today now,
don't I?

447
00:26:26.310 --> 00:26:27.780
>> Teaching by counter example.

448
00:26:27.780 --> 00:26:29.470
It's one of my favorite methods.

449
00:26:29.470 --> 00:26:32.694
I'm gonna show you the things not to do,
so don't do them.

450
00:26:32.694 --> 00:26:36.000
Do as I say, not as I do,
that's an important point to remember.

451
00:26:36.000 --> 00:26:39.480
>> And you can totally double-click,
it's not wrong,

452
00:26:39.480 --> 00:26:41.079
if you wanna open up, it's just.

453
00:26:42.350 --> 00:26:44.640
I'm expecting it to open
up the single one and

454
00:26:44.640 --> 00:26:47.720
I'm not even understanding what I'm doing.

455
00:26:47.720 --> 00:26:50.169
Wow, cuz you feel like,
and you're teaching us?

456
00:26:50.169 --> 00:26:53.940
[LAUGH] But back here to in the message,

457
00:26:53.940 --> 00:26:58.210
cuz there's always more
than one wrong [LAUGH].

458
00:26:58.210 --> 00:27:02.160
>> There's always more than one
way to accomplish the same task.

459
00:27:02.160 --> 00:27:05.340
And that's pretty uniform

460
00:27:05.340 --> 00:27:07.830
So if you're like,
well I found this other way,

461
00:27:07.830 --> 00:27:12.590
you very well may have, but we go
through the more commonly accepted ones.

462
00:27:12.590 --> 00:27:16.870
>> And I was trying to say,
there's more than one right way and

463
00:27:16.870 --> 00:27:20.860
I one more wrong way and
I was like, ew, okay that is too.

464
00:27:20.860 --> 00:27:24.020
>> But behind my head just to show
you that in the bottom of this

465
00:27:24.020 --> 00:27:28.370
drop down I have Print, so
I could go ahead and take this message,

466
00:27:28.370 --> 00:27:33.220
send it out to my printer options,
there we go.

467
00:27:33.220 --> 00:27:35.715
So now I have, wow, here we go, yay.

468
00:27:35.715 --> 00:27:40.960
[LAUGH] My Edge is configuring and
trying to find the printer

469
00:27:40.960 --> 00:27:46.040
that this is connected to and this is a
networked printer over in the over office.

470
00:27:46.040 --> 00:27:47.400
So I could take and

471
00:27:47.400 --> 00:27:52.920
change any of the options that I
might need to have this printed out.

472
00:27:52.920 --> 00:27:55.430
Now this is connected to your browser.

473
00:27:55.430 --> 00:28:00.860
So depending on what browser
you have your print dialog box

474
00:28:00.860 --> 00:28:03.700
could look different, I am using Edge.

475
00:28:03.700 --> 00:28:05.250
So if you're using Chrome or

476
00:28:05.250 --> 00:28:09.340
Safari you might have a little bit
different things going on here.

477
00:28:09.340 --> 00:28:12.990
But the concept is if I wanted to
print where do I find the button?

478
00:28:12.990 --> 00:28:17.510
It's in that actions button on that
particular email, and then you could send

479
00:28:17.510 --> 00:28:22.070
it to your printer and draw pretty little
pictures all over it if you wanted to.

480
00:28:23.270 --> 00:28:26.540
>> Well Vonne, you've definitively
eliminated a few things for us, and

481
00:28:26.540 --> 00:28:28.170
by a few things, I mean a lot.

482
00:28:28.170 --> 00:28:30.420
There was a great deal there.

483
00:28:30.420 --> 00:28:33.780
And remember, carbon copy, too, and
blind carbon copy, to some extent,

484
00:28:33.780 --> 00:28:35.290
it's a semantic difference.

485
00:28:35.290 --> 00:28:37.370
But it's an important one to remember.

486
00:28:37.370 --> 00:28:40.680
Also that print function that
she was just talking about.

487
00:28:40.680 --> 00:28:43.930
If you're an unsupported browser,
you may get some weird print.

488
00:28:43.930 --> 00:28:49.600
Like it'll actually print the Outlook
interface instead of the actual email.

489
00:28:49.600 --> 00:28:52.535
So if you get some weirdness,
you may have to try out another browser.

490
00:28:52.535 --> 00:28:56.090
But we're not done with actually
interacting with email, so

491
00:28:56.090 --> 00:28:58.720
you should join us back for a part three.

492
00:28:58.720 --> 00:29:00.780
But for now, we're gonna go ahead and
sign off for OfficeProTV.

493
00:29:00.780 --> 00:29:02.390
I've been your host Justin Dennison.

494
00:29:02.390 --> 00:29:03.170
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

495
00:29:03.170 --> 00:29:07.043
>> We'll see you next time.

496
00:29:07.043 --> 00:29:09.690
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore the basics of emailing. Specifically in this episode, what to do when email is undeliverable, advanced attachment options, managing received email resources, and what is in the trash bin.
episodes.title: Mail Basics Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.793
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.793 --> 00:00:09.446
Greetings everyone and welcome to
another exciting episode of OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:09.446 --> 00:00:10.619
I'm your host Justin Dennison.

4
00:00:10.619 --> 00:00:13.439
And well we're coming
back with a part three.

5
00:00:13.439 --> 00:00:17.297
Yeah, a part three on mail basics for
Outlook on the web.

6
00:00:17.297 --> 00:00:21.069
And here to help us along, to make sure
we don't get lost and wonder off, Ms.

7
00:00:21.069 --> 00:00:21.790
Vonne Smith.

8
00:00:21.790 --> 00:00:22.730
How do you doing today, Vonne?

9
00:00:22.730 --> 00:00:25.032
>> I'm good.
Talking about wandering off,

10
00:00:25.032 --> 00:00:30.428
we're gonna talk about missing attachments
that have somehow just wandered off and

11
00:00:30.428 --> 00:00:34.311
not gone on to my email,
which I have done a couple times too.

12
00:00:34.311 --> 00:00:37.606
[LAUGH] We are people just like you.

13
00:00:37.606 --> 00:00:41.482
And yeah, I have sent an email off
that says, hey, just go ahead and

14
00:00:41.482 --> 00:00:44.280
make sure you look at
everything on this report.

15
00:00:44.280 --> 00:00:48.170
Sent it out to 25 people, and I start
getting like no attachment, no attachment.

16
00:00:48.170 --> 00:00:51.364
I'm like, sorry, and
I had to bring it on back.

17
00:00:51.364 --> 00:00:55.950
So we can always make sure that,
that is actually a point right there is

18
00:00:55.950 --> 00:00:59.320
always check your email
before you send it.

19
00:00:59.320 --> 00:01:02.390
And checking your name,
am I addressing it to the right person?

20
00:01:02.390 --> 00:01:03.860
Do I have the subject line?

21
00:01:03.860 --> 00:01:06.840
Did I attach the file that I
said I was going to attach?

22
00:01:06.840 --> 00:01:08.830
And did I spell everything right?

23
00:01:08.830 --> 00:01:12.050
Did I say from, instead of form?

24
00:01:12.050 --> 00:01:14.613
Proofing is always a good thing to do.

25
00:01:14.613 --> 00:01:19.002
And the nice thing about these attachments
that may have wandered off the page, or

26
00:01:19.002 --> 00:01:21.878
really wandered off from
our memory of attaching it.

27
00:01:21.878 --> 00:01:24.900
At least you have a little bit
of a warning system in here.

28
00:01:24.900 --> 00:01:26.570
So I wanna show you what that means.

29
00:01:26.570 --> 00:01:30.187
And we're also gonna talk about,
hey I had sent it to the wrong person and

30
00:01:30.187 --> 00:01:33.625
I got a warning, and we're gonna
do a like, yeah that was actually,

31
00:01:33.625 --> 00:01:37.745
yes there is a button that looks just like
this, and we're gonna like some stuff.

32
00:01:37.745 --> 00:01:40.780
And then we're gonna talk
about deleting our emails.

33
00:01:40.780 --> 00:01:42.900
Let's jump on in.

34
00:01:42.900 --> 00:01:45.420
We've got Joey's email here.

35
00:01:45.420 --> 00:01:47.395
Undeliverable emails.

36
00:01:47.395 --> 00:01:50.773
Now I went head in send off two emails,

37
00:01:50.773 --> 00:01:56.800
well I never actually sent them off,
because I typed them in wrong.

38
00:01:56.800 --> 00:02:02.210
And notice here in my inbox,
I have from Microsoft Outlook that I have

39
00:02:02.210 --> 00:02:08.666
this little icon right there, that looks
like arrows with little lines off of it.

40
00:02:08.666 --> 00:02:14.391
This is an indication to me that
I have an undeliverable message,

41
00:02:14.391 --> 00:02:17.420
I have a warning, let's open it.

42
00:02:17.420 --> 00:02:21.980
Open this from Microsoft Outlook and
it is saying I did that double clicking.

43
00:02:21.980 --> 00:02:24.889
Again, I think it's just double click day,
you know what?

44
00:02:24.889 --> 00:02:29.492
That's what we're going to deem this as,
nothing wrong with it, but it says,

45
00:02:29.492 --> 00:02:33.202
I can't request, actually,
[LAUGH] it just saying, no Vonne,

46
00:02:33.202 --> 00:02:37.087
you ain't gonna have it so-
>> You have already double clicked it into

47
00:02:37.087 --> 00:02:39.027
non existence, you went click happy

48
00:02:39.027 --> 00:02:40.216
>> [LAUGH]
>> And it's broke.

49
00:02:40.216 --> 00:02:42.840
>> [LAUGH]
>> So what should we do?

50
00:02:42.840 --> 00:02:46.550
Well I always like the IT go to,
have you tried cutting it off and

51
00:02:46.550 --> 00:02:48.092
turning it back on again.

52
00:02:48.092 --> 00:02:49.219
And in this case,

53
00:02:49.219 --> 00:02:53.740
closing the window and seeing what
happens if we try to bring it back up.

54
00:02:53.740 --> 00:02:54.866
>> Yeah, I broke the internet.

55
00:02:54.866 --> 00:02:59.640
[LAUGH] With all of my famous things of,
hey I double click too much.

56
00:02:59.640 --> 00:03:03.716
So back in here as I have single
clicked to select this and

57
00:03:03.716 --> 00:03:06.332
show it in the main area right here.

58
00:03:06.332 --> 00:03:10.906
It tells me that,
delivery has failed to these recipients.

59
00:03:10.906 --> 00:03:14.921
And if I look at what is wrong with this,

60
00:03:14.921 --> 00:03:19.910
that was a whole,
I had Lance's email in there,

61
00:03:19.910 --> 00:03:25.690
in the suggested ones and
it's doing the wrong one.

62
00:03:25.690 --> 00:03:31.910
So it's in the format of
what an email needs to have.

63
00:03:31.910 --> 00:03:33.560
There's nothing wrong with this.

64
00:03:33.560 --> 00:03:37.985
It has a name, it has an at symbol,
so that's fine.

65
00:03:37.985 --> 00:03:42.490
Officeprodemoco.com, so
it has a top level domain.

66
00:03:42.490 --> 00:03:46.940
It has the sub domain if you wanna call it
or the main address, and it has a name and

67
00:03:46.940 --> 00:03:47.720
it has an at symbol.

68
00:03:47.720 --> 00:03:52.400
So there would be nothing wrong
when I check the name of this.

69
00:03:52.400 --> 00:03:55.080
I'll tell you what I mean, and I'll
demonstrate that in just a second when I

70
00:03:55.080 --> 00:03:59.120
make a new email and I'll show
you the check name functionality.

71
00:03:59.120 --> 00:04:01.110
But it wouldn't have caught this.

72
00:04:01.110 --> 00:04:06.480
It kind of goes back to the beginning
of the show where I said always proof.

73
00:04:06.480 --> 00:04:10.200
This would not come up as a mistake,
it's correct,

74
00:04:10.200 --> 00:04:13.220
but you missed the whole other part of it.

75
00:04:13.220 --> 00:04:16.530
So it's letting you know
that it can't be received.

76
00:04:16.530 --> 00:04:21.213
And this is where reading your
undeliverable messages that come back

77
00:04:21.213 --> 00:04:24.937
from Microsoft Outlook or
just Microsoft in general.

78
00:04:24.937 --> 00:04:28.006
Read these,
now sometimes you might feel like, okay,

79
00:04:28.006 --> 00:04:31.875
the DNS report the recipient like,
I don't even know what DNS means.

80
00:04:31.875 --> 00:04:37.550
But at least sometimes it will show
you maybe there's a size limitation,

81
00:04:37.550 --> 00:04:42.230
or not receivable, or
email doesn't exist, so read them.

82
00:04:42.230 --> 00:04:47.209
Sometimes you can decipher, hey that
person just doesn't exist anymore or

83
00:04:47.209 --> 00:04:52.108
they can't receive my email, because
my attachment is too large to be able

84
00:04:52.108 --> 00:04:55.170
to go through the channels
that it needs to be.

85
00:04:55.170 --> 00:05:01.570
So watch these ones, let me go back and
close here, come back to another delivery.

86
00:05:02.800 --> 00:05:04.837
And I clicked it again.

87
00:05:04.837 --> 00:05:06.110
>> You do love double clicking.

88
00:05:06.110 --> 00:05:06.669
>> You know what?

89
00:05:06.669 --> 00:05:07.401
[LAUGH]
>> But

90
00:05:07.401 --> 00:05:10.490
while we're resolving that shenanigans,
right?

91
00:05:10.490 --> 00:05:12.530
Just something to reiterate.

92
00:05:12.530 --> 00:05:16.450
Typically, this message have this
top level like error, right?

93
00:05:16.450 --> 00:05:19.429
Delivery has failed to these recipients or
groups, and then you get this list.

94
00:05:20.470 --> 00:05:23.840
A lot of times the first thing I do,
before I even read the rest of it,

95
00:05:23.840 --> 00:05:28.310
is I just look back through the email real
quick, because after a second glance it's

96
00:05:28.310 --> 00:05:31.850
already went out and come back to you,
you're like, I put an extra M in there.

97
00:05:31.850 --> 00:05:32.510
That's not right.

98
00:05:33.610 --> 00:05:37.750
But keep in mind, right below those list
of emails you do get that specification.

99
00:05:37.750 --> 00:05:42.070
Sometimes it's a little tech heavy, but
you can pick out keywords like attachment,

100
00:05:42.070 --> 00:05:45.310
big or large or something like that.

101
00:05:45.310 --> 00:05:50.560
And so even if you don't know what a DNS
is or whatever, you just wanna use email.

102
00:05:50.560 --> 00:05:51.950
You can still pick out, right,

103
00:05:51.950 --> 00:05:56.200
the DNS, that's not the part I care about,
recipient's domain does not exist.

104
00:05:56.200 --> 00:05:59.080
Recipient does not exist, and
that's all you really need to know.

105
00:05:59.080 --> 00:06:03.350
That probably means that the email's down,
what I mean is it doesn't exist,

106
00:06:03.350 --> 00:06:05.670
or you've typed an extra letter or

107
00:06:05.670 --> 00:06:11.090
you mistyped something, or you just copied
it wrong or something of that nature.

108
00:06:11.090 --> 00:06:14.463
>> Or you've said Microoooosoft.

109
00:06:14.463 --> 00:06:19.422
[LAUGH] It's like okay, I've had a couple
of different o's, I forgot an i and

110
00:06:19.422 --> 00:06:23.030
this is one of those PEBCAC
errors that we love, right?

111
00:06:23.030 --> 00:06:29.148
The PEBCAC error is my favorite, it's the
problem exists between computer and chair.

112
00:06:29.148 --> 00:06:34.552
Yes, so [LAUGH] sometimes that happens.

113
00:06:34.552 --> 00:06:36.676
So check these deliverables, but

114
00:06:36.676 --> 00:06:41.813
it's usually almost immediate like when
you send it, it will kind of bounce back.

115
00:06:41.813 --> 00:06:45.360
And this is like people say,
my, your email bounced.

116
00:06:45.360 --> 00:06:49.050
This is what they're talking about,
it's like it bounced back to me and

117
00:06:49.050 --> 00:06:55.760
it didn't get out, it did not send out
pass my outbox and I never got it to you.

118
00:06:55.760 --> 00:07:00.820
The bounced emails is your undeliverables,
it happens.

119
00:07:00.820 --> 00:07:04.010
And so check those messages out.

120
00:07:04.010 --> 00:07:07.130
Now the check name that
I had mentioned before.

121
00:07:07.130 --> 00:07:08.120
Let's start a new email.

122
00:07:08.120 --> 00:07:10.770
And we're going to address this.

123
00:07:10.770 --> 00:07:13.325
And I'm gonna type this out,
and I'm gonna say

124
00:07:13.325 --> 00:07:22.930
justin@officeprodemoco.com.

125
00:07:22.930 --> 00:07:25.680
That is a valid email address.

126
00:07:25.680 --> 00:07:31.510
We talked about the at,
the dot, the top level domain.

127
00:07:31.510 --> 00:07:33.923
In the dot, dot, or the ellipses up here,

128
00:07:33.923 --> 00:07:38.010
you have the option of checking
names to make sure Hade is exist.

129
00:07:38.010 --> 00:07:42.845
If I click on that it's gonna say,
nope, it looks fine, nothing wrong.

130
00:07:42.845 --> 00:07:46.292
That could be a valid email address.

131
00:07:46.292 --> 00:07:50.630
But if you had just
typed in justin.com and

132
00:07:50.630 --> 00:07:56.788
went to check names,
see where it says, no match was found.

133
00:07:56.788 --> 00:08:00.770
If it doesn't pull out
a little bubble around it.

134
00:08:00.770 --> 00:08:02.024
Then something's wrong.

135
00:08:02.024 --> 00:08:06.270

I know without him even responding,

And the show more in the notifications,

well what other things did,
Justin liked a couple other of my emails.

Cool I like that, I like that.

I can send it back to him and

Now, before any of you all get super

Now, with that word

this is what I'm inferring from that

I think I'll share on an E level two, so

if you don't have this

So just keep a note of the specifications

Anything that goes into your deleted

I wanna take this email and put it

417

Dragging it over notice right there,

419

So recovery is good, but I really

420
00:24:41.330 --> 00:24:42.610
They need to go away.

421
00:24:42.610 --> 00:24:47.740
I want to delete the trash can or

422
00:24:47.740 --> 00:24:48.987
You could do it a couple different ways.

423
00:24:48.987 --> 00:24:53.977
I'm going to show you this one, by

425

Once I click delete all, and I'm going

427

Once you click Ok, you should think that

428
00:25:17.290 --> 00:25:20.300
Always is a good rule of thumb,

429
00:25:20.300 --> 00:25:22.890
You might need some help from IT, and

430

I would probably say,
just think they are really, really gone.

431

It is possible, we could go into a whole
nother thing about data recovery, and

432

things like that.

433

But for an end user,
you need to make sure that you're done.

434
00:25:38.645 --> 00:25:42.540
So, there is one point that I wanna

435

It does have to kinda

436
00:25:45.090 --> 00:25:51.100
Maybe every time that I close my browser

437
00:25:51.100 --> 00:25:56.840
I want everything that's in the deleted
item folder to be actually deleted gone.

438
00:25:56.840 --> 00:26:00.460
So there is a setting, and I wrote it

the settings, if we go down, behind my
head, there is the app settings for

00:26:05.420 --> 00:26:11.800
mail and
in mail we have our message options.

441
00:26:11.800 --> 00:26:16.344
So let's find, there it is,
Message options the check box for

442
00:26:16.344 --> 00:26:19.795
empty the deleted items
folder when I sign out.

443
00:26:19.795 --> 00:26:25.068
It will do exactly that, it tweet to
sound if you wanna make sure it goes away

444

especially if you have a very limited
mailbox size, you might want to do that.

445
00:26:30.606 --> 00:26:34.421
But at least I wanted to point that out so

you can get rid of all
the things you don't want to.

447
00:26:37.850 --> 00:26:41.010
>> Well Vonne, I definitely don't wanna

448

In these past three episodes
you have taken us from on

email apprentice all the way
to an email magician.

450
00:26:46.380 --> 00:26:47.570
So thank you for that.

451
00:26:47.570 --> 00:26:51.510
But we are not done with Outlook on the

00:26:51.510 --> 00:26:53.730

453
00:26:53.730 --> 00:26:55.374
But for now, we're gonna go ahead and

00:26:57.380 --> 00:26:58.220
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

456
00:26:58.220 --> 00:27:05.030
We'll see you next time.

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore and demonstrate formatting message with a focus on character and paragraph level formats.
episodes.title: Format Message Body

WEBVTT

1

[MUSIC]

[FOREIGN] to our messages, and

00:00:21.070 --> 00:00:24.310

Outlook oracle Ms. Vonne Smith.

8
00:00:24.310 --> 00:00:25.230
How are you doing today, Vonne?

9
00:00:25.230 --> 00:00:28.171
>> Wow, Outlook oracle, I sound so fancy.

10
00:00:28.171 --> 00:00:30.841
[LAUGH]
>> Well, it is meant to be fancy.

11
00:00:30.841 --> 00:00:35.374
You are the all-seeing,
the all-knowing in the land of Outlook.

12
00:00:35.374 --> 00:00:36.740
>> I love this.

13
00:00:36.740 --> 00:00:41.613
[LAUGH] Well, we are going to add
a little bit of extra pizzazz,

14
00:00:41.613 --> 00:00:44.910

15
00:00:44.910 --> 00:00:47.950
We're gonna make stuff maybe some pink and
some purple.

See some fonts here and

So I have got Justin's,

I have Joey's computer ready, and

00:01:08.980 --> 00:01:11.470

00:01:11.470 --> 00:01:13.848
I threw a new theme on my interface,

25
00:01:13.848 --> 00:01:17.188
just cuz I just wanted
a little bit of difference.

26
00:01:17.188 --> 00:01:21.268
That's the nice thing, is you can go ahead
and customize what your feeling, maybe,

27
00:01:21.268 --> 00:01:21.787
that day.

28
00:01:21.787 --> 00:01:23.064
Even though it was blue,
I'm not feeling blue.

29
00:01:23.064 --> 00:01:25.845
I'm actually feeling pretty
good about everything, but

30
00:01:25.845 --> 00:01:27.271
I thought it was very techie.

31
00:01:27.271 --> 00:01:30.808
And very ITProTV, OfficeProTV, DevProTV,

all of those wonderful TVs that we have,

33

All right, so where are we gonna start?

Well we gotta go ahead and create a new

00:01:45.382 --> 00:01:50.230
And for this one, I am gonna go ahead and

38
00:01:54.869 --> 00:01:59.452
Now, when we go ahead and

cuz we did our basic mail episodes where

Maybe you need to add
an image in a table so,

some different options
that you're gonna have.

43

But before we get started,
I do wanna make a point that,

44
00:02:18.570 --> 00:02:23.370
using Outlook on the web,
whether it's outlook.com or

45

the Office 365 version,
you have a lot less options for

46
00:02:28.270 --> 00:02:33.270
adding content or
formatting content in your messages than

47
00:02:33.270 --> 00:02:38.189
you do if you are on a desktop
version of Outlook 2016.

48
00:02:38.189 --> 00:02:42.874
So coming from a place where I
can do all of these things that I

49
00:02:42.874 --> 00:02:45.988
have insert tab and I have a review tab.

50
00:02:45.988 --> 00:02:49.477
And all of these different things
when I'm composing a message,

51
00:02:49.477 --> 00:02:51.530
like I'd be working in Word.

52
00:02:51.530 --> 00:02:56.980
Like on my local version of Outlook 2016,
you don't have as many things here.

53
00:02:56.980 --> 00:02:59.540
So it could be a good thing and
a bad thing.

54
00:02:59.540 --> 00:03:02.430
Sometimes it's like,
I don't need all of those extra features.

55
00:03:02.430 --> 00:03:05.770
I really just need to get in some
stuff from this basic content.

56
00:03:05.770 --> 00:03:10.775
And so the Outlook on the web version
might be like just what you need,

57
00:03:10.775 --> 00:03:13.640
cuz it just gives you,
well, just what you need.

58
00:03:13.640 --> 00:03:16.375
We can address this, that's fine.

59
00:03:16.375 --> 00:03:20.700
We'll address it to JT and
we will say format.

60
00:03:20.700 --> 00:03:24.310
And I am going down into my message body.

61
00:03:24.310 --> 00:03:27.597
When we start composing messages,

62
00:03:27.597 --> 00:03:32.743
you have two options of how
your content is formatted and

63
00:03:32.743 --> 00:03:36.680
that is in either HTML or plain text.

64
00:03:36.680 --> 00:03:38.830
Now HTML, what does that stand for?

65
00:03:38.830 --> 00:03:41.090
That's Hyper Text Markup Language.

66
00:03:41.090 --> 00:03:42.650
It is the language of the web.

67
00:03:42.650 --> 00:03:45.530
It's all about a series of tags and
attributes and,

68
00:03:45.530 --> 00:03:48.760
if you have no idea what I am
talking about, don't worry about it.

69
00:03:48.760 --> 00:03:52.344
You can just think that it's the format
that allowed you to do all of

70
00:03:52.344 --> 00:03:56.568
the different types of formatting like
character and paragraph formatting,

71
00:03:56.568 --> 00:03:59.324
which we'll talk a little
bit more about in detail.

72
00:03:59.324 --> 00:04:02.930
Things like adding tables,
adding images cuz that language and

73
00:04:02.930 --> 00:04:05.609
that format supports
those types of elements.

74
00:04:05.609 --> 00:04:09.110
Plain text is exactly what it's sounds.

75
00:04:09.110 --> 00:04:13.320
It's just text, you can't add color,
you can't add font.

76
00:04:13.320 --> 00:04:16.931
You can't left indent or
right indent, or write align or

77
00:04:16.931 --> 00:04:20.330
left align any of your text,
it's just text as text.

78
00:04:20.330 --> 00:04:26.030
And it's something to consider when you're
sending out messages because not all, I'm

79
00:04:26.030 --> 00:04:31.730
gonna sound a little dated right here, not
all email servers allows HTML formatting.

80
00:04:31.730 --> 00:04:34.910
Now as soon as I say that and that
comes out of my mouth, in this day and

81
00:04:34.910 --> 00:04:37.820
age, I don't know if that's
still true honestly [LAUGH].

82
00:04:37.820 --> 00:04:39.510
>> Well I can jump in here Vonne.

83
00:04:39.510 --> 00:04:44.630
I know that HTML emails are actually
limited to a subset of HTML.

84
00:04:44.630 --> 00:04:48.860
Now this is a little beyond the technical
spec, so there are still some limitations.

85
00:04:48.860 --> 00:04:54.070
But also, it's kind of nice if you know
that someone's gonna have reduced Internet

86
00:04:54.070 --> 00:04:56.890
availability and
maybe using those light versions.

87
00:04:56.890 --> 00:05:00.420
If you get plain text, well,
all you're gonna see is plain text.

88
00:05:00.420 --> 00:05:04.190
If you get the HTML version, well,
it may not render the HTML but

89
00:05:04.190 --> 00:05:08.420
instead give you the HTML representation
which, behind the scenes, is still text.

90
00:05:08.420 --> 00:05:12.550
So you've got text in text and it's gonna
be a little harder to read if, well,

91
00:05:12.550 --> 00:05:16.826
they're using some kind of client that
has, well, HTML rendering turned off.

92
00:05:16.826 --> 00:05:21.430
And there may be entities such as
government or corporate entities,

93
00:05:21.430 --> 00:05:25.340
that will still use those
just to reduce bandwidth and

94
00:05:25.340 --> 00:05:27.770
maintenance or a Legacy system.

95
00:05:27.770 --> 00:05:32.190
>> Yeah, and so it might not be
necessary that they can't support HTML.

96
00:05:32.190 --> 00:05:36.240
Yes, definitely the connections and
the different things that you need,

97
00:05:36.240 --> 00:05:39.500
I don't need all of that bandwidth, so
I wanna go ahead and condense it down.

98
00:05:39.500 --> 00:05:43.380
So that's a great example of why
you might wanna go ahead and

99
00:05:43.380 --> 00:05:47.540
use plain text rather
than HTML formatting.

100
00:05:47.540 --> 00:05:49.773
So the message bar that I have right now,

101
00:05:49.773 --> 00:05:52.937
I know right now that this
message is formatted as a HTML.

102
00:05:52.937 --> 00:05:57.907
The reason I know that is all of
these buttons down across the bottom

103
00:05:57.907 --> 00:06:00.020
of this message area.

104
00:06:00.020 --> 00:06:04.191
So all these buttons allow me to do
things, and if I hover to discover,

105
00:06:04.191 --> 00:06:07.745
change the font, change the font size,
make things bold.

106
00:06:07.745 --> 00:06:10.620
Go ahead and change the font color.

107
00:06:10.620 --> 00:06:14.973
So making sure you know what each
one of these icons does within

108
00:06:14.973 --> 00:06:19.277
your formatting is really nice
with that hover to discover.

109
00:06:19.277 --> 00:06:22.339
Now if you don't see this
bar across the bottom,

110
00:06:22.339 --> 00:06:26.995
it could be that you don't actually
see the formatting options.

111
00:06:26.995 --> 00:06:30.502
Down here on the bottom, after the right
hand side of all of our send and

112
00:06:30.502 --> 00:06:33.015
discard buttons,
there's a little carrot looking button.

113
00:06:33.015 --> 00:06:34.077
The more actions and

114
00:06:34.077 --> 00:06:38.150
you could see that it's giving me some
information right here for me to show.

115
00:06:38.150 --> 00:06:42.798
And if it didn't show all the options, you
might not see like formatting options and

116
00:06:42.798 --> 00:06:46.007
it will tell you,
like show these formatting options, or

117
00:06:46.007 --> 00:06:50.021
a lot times it will be off to the side,
over here on the right-hand side.

118
00:06:50.021 --> 00:06:54.884
But talking about that HTML in plain text,
the option to switch

119
00:06:54.884 --> 00:07:00.230
it into plain text is in that
Actions button down at the bottom.

120
00:07:00.230 --> 00:07:04.620
And if I switch it over to plain text,
it's giving me a warning right here to say

121
00:07:04.620 --> 00:07:08.450
that, hey if you'd already started
typing things in and you had formats and

122
00:07:08.450 --> 00:07:11.540
you had things that we're
using an HTML formatting,

123
00:07:11.540 --> 00:07:15.360
you're gonna lose some of that,
