realize, oops, I didn't get enough.

354
00:19:50.340 --> 00:19:55.550
If you start to drag over the selected
text and start moving it.

355
00:19:55.550 --> 00:20:01.638
You're not gonna get what you're trying to
do, you're not extending that selection.

356
00:20:01.638 --> 00:20:04.260
You're either deselecting or sometimes,
especially if you're on your desktop

357
00:20:04.260 --> 00:20:06.740
versions, you're actually moving,
you're doing the drag and drop text.

358
00:20:06.740 --> 00:20:12.180
Now, it's not doing the drag and drop text
here, but it's not doing what you want.

359
00:20:12.180 --> 00:20:16.220
So always, if you didn't do it right the
first time, click off, and do it again.

360
00:20:16.220 --> 00:20:20.288
So, click, hold, and drag, getting that
i-beam cursor over the text that I want.

361
00:20:20.288 --> 00:20:22.789
Now something else that's happening here,

362
00:20:22.789 --> 00:20:26.290
is that you get what's known as
this mini toolbar that pops up.

363
00:20:27.322 --> 00:20:30.750
This can be really handy
because maybe you're way far

364
00:20:30.750 --> 00:20:35.170
down to get to some of the buttons
that I want to get to formatting.

365
00:20:35.170 --> 00:20:40.700
It's right here over the text and
this is character level formatting only.

366
00:20:40.700 --> 00:20:43.950
You don't see the center button or
the bullet button

367
00:20:43.950 --> 00:20:47.860
because it's just showing what
you can do with the words here.

368
00:20:47.860 --> 00:20:51.220
So either from here or
down here you can go through and

369
00:20:51.220 --> 00:20:54.210
change the font that is available to you.

370
00:20:54.210 --> 00:20:59.376
Why don't I pick one,
let's go with Impact, sounds good.

371
00:20:59.376 --> 00:21:02.446
Changing the font size,
make it bigger, make it smaller.

372
00:21:02.446 --> 00:21:04.220
We'll make it a little bit bigger.

373
00:21:05.230 --> 00:21:10.171
Bold, italic and underline,
I don't know how else to explain bold,

374
00:21:10.171 --> 00:21:12.028
italic, and underline.

375
00:21:12.028 --> 00:21:13.250
[LAUGH] They just do.

376
00:21:13.250 --> 00:21:15.940
>> I can provide some different context.

377
00:21:17.100 --> 00:21:18.360
Depending on who you're talking to,

378
00:21:18.360 --> 00:21:22.030
bold can mean I really want to,
like this is important.

379
00:21:23.270 --> 00:21:28.110
Italics is for emphasis or
maybe presents with sarcasm,

380
00:21:28.110 --> 00:21:31.850
and then underline is either for
titles or something.

381
00:21:31.850 --> 00:21:36.590
Or to say really look at this,
it's kind of an extra added boom.

382
00:21:36.590 --> 00:21:41.156
But yeah, as far as what they do,
they're bold, italic, and underline.

383
00:21:41.156 --> 00:21:43.330
>> [LAUGH]
>> So there's not a lot to say about that.

384
00:21:43.330 --> 00:21:47.850
>> You can tell I do a lot of
demonstration with bold italic.

385
00:21:47.850 --> 00:21:48.970
How do I explain bold?

386
00:21:48.970 --> 00:21:53.240
It just makes it bold, it's like you're
describing the word with the word?

387
00:21:53.240 --> 00:21:55.760
Yeah, I feel like I'm almost there,
so thank you very much for

388
00:21:55.760 --> 00:21:56.916
that lovely insight there.

389
00:21:56.916 --> 00:21:59.887
And then sometimes, some fonts,
you make it bold and

390
00:21:59.887 --> 00:22:04.620
it doesn't look any different because
it's already like a thick font there.

391
00:22:04.620 --> 00:22:09.810
Again I want to try to keep it
short because I love topography and

392
00:22:09.810 --> 00:22:10.640
all about typesetting.

393
00:22:10.640 --> 00:22:12.340
So we're gonna keep on moving.

394
00:22:12.340 --> 00:22:16.300
One thing about the underline though,
if you underline something.

395
00:22:16.300 --> 00:22:19.660
Justin, sometimes what does that mean
to you if some text is underlined?

396
00:22:20.690 --> 00:22:25.255
>> It's a title or
a heading or it's underlined?

397
00:22:25.255 --> 00:22:27.390
>> [LAUGH] Or a link?

398
00:22:28.640 --> 00:22:30.120
>> Yes, yes.

399
00:22:30.120 --> 00:22:33.770
See, you made me look silly there, Oracle.

400
00:22:33.770 --> 00:22:36.970
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's okay though, she cast her spell.

401
00:22:36.970 --> 00:22:38.130
But, yeah, if it's a link.

402
00:22:38.130 --> 00:22:41.460
But usually I think of links of
having a different color as well.

403
00:22:41.460 --> 00:22:45.410
But yeah, a lot of times in emails,
if it's underlined, you should be careful.

404
00:22:45.410 --> 00:22:46.750
Because it may be a link,

405
00:22:46.750 --> 00:22:50.710
even if it isn't a different color cuz
someone can make it the same text color.

406
00:22:50.710 --> 00:22:54.878
You can change that and I'm sure we'll
get to all that fun stuff [INAUDIBLE]

407
00:22:54.878 --> 00:22:56.360
>> [LAUGH] And I've done that before,

408
00:22:56.360 --> 00:22:57.455
where I'm clicking on things.

409
00:22:57.455 --> 00:23:00.800
I'm like, why isn't this,
you just underlined it.

410
00:23:00.800 --> 00:23:02.390
So maybe it's more of like a me thing,

411
00:23:02.390 --> 00:23:06.760
like my head thinks, hey if it's
underlined it's gonna be a link.

412
00:23:06.760 --> 00:23:08.750
But, good, that was fun [LAUGH].

413
00:23:08.750 --> 00:23:11.730
So if I go over here to
high lighting the text,

414
00:23:11.730 --> 00:23:14.830
that's just changing like
the background color of that text.

415
00:23:14.830 --> 00:23:18.212
Maybe I'll make it yellow, and you don't
see it right now cuz it's still selected.

416
00:23:18.212 --> 00:23:25.420
And let's change the font color to purple,
click off of it, there we go.

417
00:23:25.420 --> 00:23:29.490
I have applied character
formatting to this text.

418
00:23:29.490 --> 00:23:32.870
So I could do that with as
many words as I select,

419
00:23:32.870 --> 00:23:37.050
whether it's a few words,
in a paragraph, the entire paragraph,

420
00:23:37.050 --> 00:23:41.455
the entire line,
just those words have that formatting.

421
00:23:41.455 --> 00:23:47.290
Center, left, and right align, that
would be a paragraph level formatting.

422
00:23:47.290 --> 00:23:50.190
And I know that there is a paragraph
because right here I can

423
00:23:50.190 --> 00:23:53.101
see where the line has broken and
it's starting another.

424
00:23:53.101 --> 00:23:58.136
Now, I want to stop myself
because you could have something

425
00:23:58.136 --> 00:24:03.573
known as line break to where it
is- It's not a carriage return,

426
00:24:03.573 --> 00:24:07.000
like a full paragraph Enter mark.

427
00:24:07.000 --> 00:24:10.403
It is a Shift+Enter or
breaking the line that starts it, but

428
00:24:10.403 --> 00:24:12.685
it's still part of the same paragraph.

429
00:24:12.685 --> 00:24:17.559
I can't really tell that right now, but as
soon as I start making some formattings,

430
00:24:17.559 --> 00:24:21.074
I would be able to do that,
I just wanna throw that out there.

431
00:24:21.074 --> 00:24:23.668
I'm gonna select this
paragraph right here, and

432
00:24:23.668 --> 00:24:27.385
then down here I have left aligned,
which it's already left aligned.

433
00:24:27.385 --> 00:24:31.132
I have centered aligned, which then
goes ahead and center aligns this

434
00:24:31.132 --> 00:24:35.653
whole paragraph and, now this is where,
notice how I've selected just this.

435
00:24:35.653 --> 00:24:40.333
I didn't actually plan for it to do
that but this is a perfect example of,

436
00:24:40.333 --> 00:24:44.888
I selected this, but It's actually
centering this, this and this.

437
00:24:44.888 --> 00:24:49.135
But these aren't, right,
so why is that happening?

438
00:24:49.135 --> 00:24:50.648
That was an example of,

439
00:24:50.648 --> 00:24:55.180
it doesn't think that this is
a separate paragraph right now.

440
00:24:55.180 --> 00:24:59.773
If I hit Enter here,
select this paragraph, come over and

441
00:24:59.773 --> 00:25:04.668
make that left, you see how it
did not affect this paragraph.

442
00:25:04.668 --> 00:25:07.905
So this is where it can
get a little weird,

443
00:25:07.905 --> 00:25:14.023
see how it did all of it where I thought
it was just gonna do one, but it did both.

444
00:25:14.023 --> 00:25:20.081
Those are kind of those hidden
syntax that you can't see sometimes,

445
00:25:20.081 --> 00:25:23.860
of line breaks versus paragraph returns.

446
00:25:23.860 --> 00:25:28.246
So just be careful about that, and if I
needed it to be separate, like this needs

447
00:25:28.246 --> 00:25:32.643
to be right aligned, the other needs to
be centered, and this needs to be left.

448
00:25:32.643 --> 00:25:37.262
Putting your cursor into the place
where you need to make a new paragraph,

449
00:25:37.262 --> 00:25:42.403
that will separate out, because I can
have different paragraph formatting for,

450
00:25:42.403 --> 00:25:44.790
well, different paragraphs.

451
00:25:44.790 --> 00:25:48.527
So that can throw things off here and
there, but

452
00:25:48.527 --> 00:25:50.967
at least you know how to fix it.

453
00:25:50.967 --> 00:25:54.040
What if I wanted to make
something into a bulleted list?

454
00:25:54.040 --> 00:25:59.790
You select the text, I want to have these
be a numbered list or a bulleted list.

455
00:25:59.790 --> 00:26:01.430
Either one, these are in HTML,

456
00:26:01.430 --> 00:26:06.830
this is ol and ul,
an ordered list versus an unordered list.

457
00:26:06.830 --> 00:26:07.830
Don't need to know that, but

458
00:26:07.830 --> 00:26:11.050
if you think ordered, numbered,
unordered, it's just bullets.

459
00:26:11.050 --> 00:26:15.974
I can click on these different ones here,
make it either numbers or bullets,

460
00:26:15.974 --> 00:26:18.269
I'm gonna put these into bullets.

461
00:26:18.269 --> 00:26:23.339
If I clicked here, because I needed
another level, say I needed to have

462
00:26:23.339 --> 00:26:29.271
a pool of tiers, but I need to have like a
sublist, or a nested list as it's called.

463
00:26:29.271 --> 00:26:32.101
You can hit Enter because
it's still going to,

464
00:26:32.101 --> 00:26:36.420
anytime you hit Enter after a paragraph
that has paragraph formatting,

465
00:26:36.420 --> 00:26:40.830
it's going to retain that level of
formatting when you go to the next one.

466
00:26:40.830 --> 00:26:44.189
So you see how it's
staying in a bullet here,

467
00:26:45.610 --> 00:26:48.268
that's all right, though,
cuz I want to go in one.

468
00:26:48.268 --> 00:26:52.455
The easiest way to do that in,
like writing text in a paragraph,

469
00:26:52.455 --> 00:26:54.147
is just hit the Tab key.

470
00:26:54.147 --> 00:26:57.618
If you hit the Tab key,
that's going to indent yourself, and

471
00:26:57.618 --> 00:27:00.541
make you into that particular
level of your list.

472
00:27:00.541 --> 00:27:04.954
I can say sub topic 1,
hit Enter again, and

473
00:27:04.954 --> 00:27:10.517
then it's going to go ahead and
give me sub topic 2.

474
00:27:10.517 --> 00:27:14.681
Let's say I need another paragraph or
another, in this sense,

475
00:27:14.681 --> 00:27:16.542
these are chapters, sorry.

476
00:27:16.542 --> 00:27:21.232
I wanna do another paragraph
chapter [LAUGH], hit Enter.

477
00:27:21.232 --> 00:27:26.304
I wanna get back out though, I don't
wanna be in this same indented level.

478
00:27:26.304 --> 00:27:31.188
Tab to get in, Shift+Tab,
hold your Shift key, click the Tab key,

479
00:27:31.188 --> 00:27:36.080
and it'll take you out one level,
and then I can say new chapter here.

480
00:27:36.080 --> 00:27:40.482
So I already had text typed in that I
wanted to select and then format after it,

481
00:27:40.482 --> 00:27:43.622
but say you went ahead and
said, I want to start a list.

482
00:27:43.622 --> 00:27:47.036
And you click the bullet button, and
you start typing, and you hit Enter, and

483
00:27:47.036 --> 00:27:47.775
you keep going.

484
00:27:47.775 --> 00:27:54.250
That's how you could do your indenting and
outdenting, as I call it.

485
00:27:54.250 --> 00:27:57.440
And any time if I hit Enter
in this particular paragraph,

486
00:27:57.440 --> 00:27:59.210
I don't want to have the bullets.

487
00:27:59.210 --> 00:28:02.570
You just come down here and
you turn the bullets off, and

488
00:28:02.570 --> 00:28:05.790
then it's an on or off type of thing.

489
00:28:07.530 --> 00:28:08.664
Now, the last thing,

490
00:28:08.664 --> 00:28:12.327
because I think we're getting towards
the end of our episode here, so.

491
00:28:12.327 --> 00:28:17.140
>> Yes you are absolutely correct,
it is, we're running nigh on time.

492
00:28:17.140 --> 00:28:19.736
>> [LAUGH] Well let me show you this one,
and

493
00:28:19.736 --> 00:28:23.283
that will complete our
paragraph level formatting.

494
00:28:23.283 --> 00:28:28.297
And then we'll move on to some of
the other stuff that I want to talk about.

495
00:28:28.297 --> 00:28:30.884
I think we might have a few parts here,
Justin.

496
00:28:30.884 --> 00:28:33.989
>> We may do it, but
that's all right, because, well,

497
00:28:33.989 --> 00:28:39.200
you're gonna have beautiful, a little, how
do you say, wonderful emails, right, so.

498
00:28:39.200 --> 00:28:39.957
>> Yeah, gorgeous.

499
00:28:39.957 --> 00:28:43.503
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> Just, I am at a lost of words.

500
00:28:43.503 --> 00:28:45.296
>> [LAUGH] I know right?

501
00:28:45.296 --> 00:28:48.581
And I'm looking at this and I'm like,
I'm not sure if we can categorize this as

502
00:28:48.581 --> 00:28:51.150
gorgeous, but you know what,
we'll run with it, so [LAUGH].

503
00:28:51.150 --> 00:28:55.486
I have this paragraph, let's go ahead and
make this left aligned for now.

504
00:28:55.486 --> 00:29:00.590
Because the other things that you can do
are known as, you can go ahead and indent.

505
00:29:00.590 --> 00:29:05.671
If I indent it, let's decrease,
if I indent, I'm pulling in what

506
00:29:05.671 --> 00:29:10.765
we call from the margins in here,
and I'm indenting my paragraph.

507
00:29:10.765 --> 00:29:14.101
If I click it again,
notice that it's indenting even more.

508
00:29:14.101 --> 00:29:17.491
So if you ever needed to do that and
kinda force it over,

509
00:29:17.491 --> 00:29:22.600
maybe you wanna add a little emphasis, or
this is a quote, you can do that as well.

510
00:29:22.600 --> 00:29:24.199
Now, back on those lists,

511
00:29:24.199 --> 00:29:27.196
cuz I was telling you to do your Tabs and
Shift+Tabs.

512
00:29:27.196 --> 00:29:31.285
These buttons, these indenting,
increase indent and

513
00:29:31.285 --> 00:29:35.600
decrease indent,
they also work in your list levels.

514
00:29:35.600 --> 00:29:40.069
For example, if I click my cursor, cuz I
gotta put my cursor into the place that

515
00:29:40.069 --> 00:29:44.976
I want to change, and also take notice,
I'm not selecting the text that's in here.

516
00:29:44.976 --> 00:29:47.864
Because any time you have
paragraph level formatting,

517
00:29:47.864 --> 00:29:51.560
you actually don't have to select
all the words within the paragraph.

518
00:29:51.560 --> 00:29:57.080
Because that level of formatting
will apply to the whole paragraph.

519
00:29:57.080 --> 00:30:01.420
I put my cursor where I want here,
and if I click this increase indent,

520
00:30:01.420 --> 00:30:04.451
notice that it will then
indent that list level.

521
00:30:04.451 --> 00:30:09.283
Or, with the cursor where I want it,
I can decrease this indent.

522
00:30:09.283 --> 00:30:14.003
So if you don't like to do
the Shift+Tab and the Tabs to go in and

523
00:30:14.003 --> 00:30:20.255
out of your list levels, you can use these
buttons to increase or decrease as well.

524
00:30:20.255 --> 00:30:25.549
So, that actually does cover all of
the character level formating and

525
00:30:25.549 --> 00:30:29.587
paragraph level formating
that is available to you,

526
00:30:29.587 --> 00:30:32.563
when you're using Outlook on the web.

527
00:30:32.563 --> 00:30:34.533
And so we will continue from there.

528
00:30:34.533 --> 00:30:37.681
>> Well, sounds like we're gonna
have a part two, maybe even a part,

529
00:30:37.681 --> 00:30:39.958
who knows how many parts
we're gonna have here.

530
00:30:39.958 --> 00:30:43.496
But I do know that we have a lot more
formatting that is available to us

531
00:30:43.496 --> 00:30:45.933
when we're using kind
of this richer editor.

532
00:30:45.933 --> 00:30:50.441
And if you've been around for a while,
you know that email used to just be,

533
00:30:50.441 --> 00:30:52.527
you type the text and you hit Send.

534
00:30:52.527 --> 00:30:55.790
But our oracle has definitely
illuminated our way for us.

535
00:30:55.790 --> 00:30:59.897
But we do have more, so continue with
us as we look at Outlook on the web.

536
00:30:59.897 --> 00:31:02.507
But for now, we're gonna go ahead and
sign off for OfficeProTV.

537
00:31:02.507 --> 00:31:03.588
I've been your host, Justin Dennison.

538
00:31:03.588 --> 00:31:04.520
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

539
00:31:04.520 --> 00:31:06.218
>> We'll see you next time.

540
00:31:06.218 --> 00:31:11.801

episodes.title: Format Message Body Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.333 --> 00:00:05.767
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.767 --> 00:00:09.370
Greetings, everyone, and welcome to
another exciting episode of Office Pro.TV.

3
00:00:09.370 --> 00:00:12.930
I'm your host, Justin Dennison, and well,
we're back with more Outlook on the Web,

4
00:00:12.930 --> 00:00:16.670
and we're in the part two
of formatting our messages.

5
00:00:16.670 --> 00:00:19.910
And here to help us along, well,
our journey through the Outlook

6
00:00:21.200 --> 00:00:24.510
landscape is our very own Outlook oracle,
Ms. Vonne Smith.

7
00:00:24.510 --> 00:00:25.490
How are you doing today, Vonne?

8
00:00:25.490 --> 00:00:28.710
>> Yes,
I decided to come back on my Falcor, and

9
00:00:28.710 --> 00:00:32.280
tell you all about the wonderful
world of message formatting.

10
00:00:32.280 --> 00:00:34.804
And like he said, we are continuing on.

11
00:00:34.804 --> 00:00:38.556
In part one, we talked about our
character and paragraph level formatting,

12
00:00:38.556 --> 00:00:42.727
and some of the AutoCorrect options, and
features that happen within your browser.

13
00:00:42.727 --> 00:00:47.792
So now we're going to start adding
some other content within our HTML

14
00:00:47.792 --> 00:00:53.060
formatted messages, to allow for
images, hyperlinks and tables.

15
00:00:53.060 --> 00:00:54.460
So let's jump back in.

16
00:00:54.460 --> 00:00:57.610
I'm actually right where we
left off in our part one,

17
00:00:57.610 --> 00:00:59.780
as we were going down that rabbit hole.

18
00:00:59.780 --> 00:01:04.260
And we decided to make this some purple
text with some yellow highlighting,

19
00:01:04.260 --> 00:01:08.670
we did our different paragraph level
formatting with our alignments and

20
00:01:08.670 --> 00:01:12.387
our bulleted, and
our numbered list in the different levels.

21
00:01:12.387 --> 00:01:16.072
A few more little tiny things about
some character level formattings,

22
00:01:16.072 --> 00:01:19.946
to really just go through each one of
these buttons before we get into what

23
00:01:19.946 --> 00:01:23.810
these little loopy things look like,
which are insert hyperlink.

24
00:01:23.810 --> 00:01:28.615
You have some other character
formattings which would be superscript,

25
00:01:28.615 --> 00:01:30.749
subscript and strike through.

26
00:01:30.749 --> 00:01:34.396
So these are things that you would
have to add to specific characters.

27
00:01:34.396 --> 00:01:38.400
So that's that character level formatting
versus that paragraph level formatting.

28
00:01:38.400 --> 00:01:43.180
So for example, if for some reason I
needed sub topic 1 to be almost like

29
00:01:43.180 --> 00:01:48.660
an exponent, sub topic to the 1,
which isn't it always itself?

over there on the left hand side for

255
00:14:58.900 --> 00:15:03.500
you to be able to remove this
picture if you wanted to.

256
00:15:04.880 --> 00:15:06.080
And I guess one last thing.

257
00:15:06.080 --> 00:15:12.195
Sorry, there's a last, last thing,
is that there's no text wrap on an image.

258
00:15:12.195 --> 00:15:15.856
If I took this image, and
let's go ahead and cut this.

259
00:15:15.856 --> 00:15:20.841
I'm going to do a Ctrl+X to get to cut,
and I come up into here, and

260
00:15:20.841 --> 00:15:25.662
then I come into the middle of
my paragraph, and then I Ctrl+V.

261
00:15:25.662 --> 00:15:29.324
I can't take this and move it around and
have the text go to the left or

262
00:15:29.324 --> 00:15:31.100
to the right of this image.

263
00:15:31.100 --> 00:15:34.520
It doesn't really like that very well.

264
00:15:34.520 --> 00:15:40.300
So just know that if you're used to
being able to use some of these advanced

265
00:15:40.300 --> 00:15:44.730
formattings of images in your Outlook for
your desktop like Outlook 2016,

266
00:15:44.730 --> 00:15:49.840
you don't have that same capabilities
here in the Outlook for web.

267
00:15:49.840 --> 00:15:54.435
So I'm gonna go ahead and just click
that undo button a couple of times and,

268
00:15:54.435 --> 00:15:55.790
there we go, keep on moving down.

269
00:15:56.830 --> 00:15:58.240
Maybe undo one more time.

270
00:15:58.240 --> 00:15:58.770
There we go.

271
00:15:58.770 --> 00:16:02.362
Yeah, just keep on clicking
until you get backwards, and

272
00:16:02.362 --> 00:16:05.678
there we have our insert images and
how we can do that.

273
00:16:05.678 --> 00:16:09.580
You could always insert an emoji
which are kind of cute now.

274
00:16:09.580 --> 00:16:13.564
I've gotten emails from people and it puts
like the little boxes with an x on it,

275
00:16:13.564 --> 00:16:15.770
have you ever gotten one of those, Justin?

276
00:16:15.770 --> 00:16:19.770
>> I haven't and they don't have a the
emoji set, essentially the character set

277
00:16:19.770 --> 00:16:22.620
in order to render the emojis, and you're
just like I don't know what you're saying.

278
00:16:22.620 --> 00:16:24.562
>> Yeah.
>> It just looks like you went x x x x.

279
00:16:24.562 --> 00:16:27.935
I was like, is it, are you trying to
tell me, am I fired or something?

280
00:16:27.935 --> 00:16:29.230
>> [LAUGH]
>> What happened?

281
00:16:29.230 --> 00:16:30.850
But yeah,
I've gotten things like that as well.

282
00:16:30.850 --> 00:16:35.174
>> Yeah and the emoji set that
is here in Outlook for web,

283
00:16:35.174 --> 00:16:38.120
if we go down here to the little emoji.

284
00:16:38.120 --> 00:16:41.340
They don't, of course I picked a bunny,
somewhere in there, but

285
00:16:41.340 --> 00:16:46.900
they don't look like the same
emojis that I have on my iPhone and

286
00:16:46.900 --> 00:16:49.490
I don't know if the coding
behind it is the same.

287
00:16:49.490 --> 00:16:53.148
And it's funny cuz once I've gotten
back on Outlook for web, or read it,

288
00:16:53.148 --> 00:16:56.157
I'm like,
that's it the emoji that they're seeing,

289
00:16:56.157 --> 00:17:00.012
versus I'm in my Gmail and it's the same
one, I'm like, what's going on.

290
00:17:00.012 --> 00:17:04.762
So some of these don't always translate
but it is cute to go ahead and

291
00:17:04.762 --> 00:17:09.108
add a little smiley face in there
if you wanted to add an emoji,

292
00:17:09.108 --> 00:17:11.218
a little graphical fun there.

293
00:17:11.218 --> 00:17:15.880
The last element that you can add into
your message body would be a table.

294
00:17:15.880 --> 00:17:22.223
Now, a table is a set of information
that is in a row and column or

295
00:17:22.223 --> 00:17:28.090
a tabular format and where columns and
rows intersect are known as cells.

296
00:17:28.090 --> 00:17:29.720
It's actually behind my head.

297
00:17:29.720 --> 00:17:35.810
The button down over here that looks like
a table is where you can insert table.

298
00:17:35.810 --> 00:17:38.730
Now I'm gonna go ahead and
make a pretty small one for now.

299
00:17:38.730 --> 00:17:42.240
Let's go with a three by two.

300
00:17:42.240 --> 00:17:46.011
So that means I'm doing three columns,
two rows.

301
00:17:46.011 --> 00:17:49.711
So you just hover over
the amount of boxes, we'll say,

302
00:17:49.711 --> 00:17:53.230
to say this is the amount of rows and
columns I want.

303
00:17:53.230 --> 00:17:55.210
You click it and it goes ahead and
puts a table in.

304
00:17:56.310 --> 00:18:00.070
To go ahead and put text into the table
you can either use your cursor

305
00:18:00.070 --> 00:18:05.310
to click your cursor into the cell that
you want the information to go into and

306
00:18:05.310 --> 00:18:07.280
then you can type in the information.

307
00:18:07.280 --> 00:18:08.770
I'm just going to say text.

308
00:18:10.750 --> 00:18:15.100
To get to the next cell over, you can hit
your tab key but of course using your

309
00:18:15.100 --> 00:18:21.290
mouse, there's nothing wrong with that and
I can type in text and I can type in text.

310
00:18:21.290 --> 00:18:23.530
Don't hit the enter key at that last row.

311
00:18:23.530 --> 00:18:24.990
You hit the tab key.

312
00:18:24.990 --> 00:18:29.340
So if you're familiar with working
in tables from other programs,

313
00:18:29.340 --> 00:18:31.797
that tab and moving around this fine.

314
00:18:31.797 --> 00:18:37.712
I wanna point out though that using
tables in Outlook for web, it's not as,

315
00:18:37.712 --> 00:18:44.790
I wanna say fluid as working with tables
in Outlook 2016 on the desktop version.

316
00:18:44.790 --> 00:18:49.680
For example if I wanted to
change the colors of the cells,

317
00:18:49.680 --> 00:18:57.930
I can't select the text or select empty
cells and say do things like merge cells.

318
00:18:57.930 --> 00:19:01.306
It's something that it's kinda ingrained
in me because that's what you would need

319
00:19:01.306 --> 00:19:04.300
to do to merge, you would need
to select them and merge them.

320
00:19:04.300 --> 00:19:07.860
It doesn't work like that necessarily.

321
00:19:07.860 --> 00:19:11.300
You have to kinda go about
it in a different way.

322
00:19:11.300 --> 00:19:14.440
It's all about where your cursor is,
right clicking.

323
00:19:14.440 --> 00:19:19.128
Just like we had right clicked on that
image to get some of the options for

324
00:19:19.128 --> 00:19:24.617
images, if I right click within this cell
within the second row, there is a merge.

325
00:19:24.617 --> 00:19:27.785
And so this is where merge
above below left and right.

326
00:19:27.785 --> 00:19:30.900
You have to do it one cell at a time.

327
00:19:30.900 --> 00:19:33.010
So to merge these three cells across,

328
00:19:33.010 --> 00:19:38.540
I would have to say let's merge to
the right and those two cells merge.

329
00:19:39.560 --> 00:19:42.670
Now that I'm in this cell,
I would right-click again and

330
00:19:42.670 --> 00:19:48.220
go with Merge right and
that's how I can get merged cells.

331
00:19:48.220 --> 00:19:53.060
If you have text inside of your cells,
you could select it but

332
00:19:53.060 --> 00:19:55.950
again you're not gonna be able
to do table formatting here.

333
00:19:55.950 --> 00:20:00.880
You're just going to be formatting the
characters or the character formatting or

334
00:20:00.880 --> 00:20:04.050
paragraph level formatting
of that particular text.

335
00:20:04.050 --> 00:20:08.420
So, just know that you're not
really selecting cells and

336
00:20:08.420 --> 00:20:13.150
formatting the cells individually,
it's only the information inside of it.

337
00:20:13.150 --> 00:20:17.291
But you do have some other limited
formatting with some styles,

338
00:20:17.291 --> 00:20:21.734
to where you could go ahead and
do like a two tone or a light banded for

339
00:20:21.734 --> 00:20:25.830
the entire table but you see then
it takes the table borders off.

340
00:20:25.830 --> 00:20:29.960
So you can put in tables,
you can add information into it.

341
00:20:29.960 --> 00:20:34.620
You can do some merging and
splitting of your cells but

342
00:20:34.620 --> 00:20:39.950
not much past that if you're
a very tabular type of person and

343
00:20:39.950 --> 00:20:43.070
have used tables in other applications.

344
00:20:43.070 --> 00:20:47.410
So it's there, just not as fluid.

345
00:20:47.410 --> 00:20:48.200
We'll just go with that.

346
00:20:48.200 --> 00:20:49.440
>> Not as fluid.

347
00:20:49.440 --> 00:20:51.240
Now Vonne, correct me if I'm wrong.

348
00:20:51.240 --> 00:20:55.590
We have a few other things but we're kind
of getting near the end of this episode.

349
00:20:55.590 --> 00:20:58.020
Should we go ahead and
make it a part three?

350
00:20:58.020 --> 00:21:01.780
>> We're going to go for that trace right
there because we're going to talk about

351
00:21:01.780 --> 00:21:05.250
copying and pasting from other
applications because sometimes I don't

352
00:21:05.250 --> 00:21:09.170
always want to type it all in myself if
somebody's already done it for me so.

353
00:21:09.170 --> 00:21:10.770
We'll go over those options as well.

354
00:21:10.770 --> 00:21:13.910
>> Well, I'm a lazy person,
that sounds like a great deal to me but

355
00:21:13.910 --> 00:21:16.830
just real quick,
you're a hockey fan, right?

356
00:21:16.830 --> 00:21:17.370
>> Yes.

357
00:21:17.370 --> 00:21:20.200
>> So three, that's a hat trick, right?

358
00:21:20.200 --> 00:21:20.990
Am I wrong?

359
00:21:22.160 --> 00:21:24.500
>> I'm beaming with pride right now.

360
00:21:24.500 --> 00:21:26.200
Yes, we're going for that hat trick.

361
00:21:26.200 --> 00:21:28.643
>> But
we are gonna have the Outlook hat trick so

362
00:21:28.643 --> 00:21:32.938
you should definitely join us back as we
finish up this message formatting but

363
00:21:32.938 --> 00:21:35.560
we're gonna go ahead and end this episode.

364
00:21:35.560 --> 00:21:38.570
So signing off for OfficeProTV,
I've been your host Justin Dennison.

365
00:21:38.570 --> 00:21:39.201
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

366
00:21:39.201 --> 00:21:41.383
>> And we'll see you next time.

367
00:21:41.383 --> 00:21:46.851
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne discuss and exhibit copying and pasting from a variety of sources.

WEBVTT

And well,

How you doing today, Vonne?

>> I'm doing fantastic.

12

We're going to continue on as
you say with our messaging and

00:00:35.690 --> 00:00:38.430
I don't like to type a lot sometimes.

Especially if it's already out there for

And, we're gonna talk

And this is where, we talked a lot about

So but we are going for

[LAUGH] So I have Joey's email up, and

I actually have a couple

Because where we are going to

Let's say we have a Word document
that has a bunch of text that's

00:01:25.410 --> 00:01:26.890

29
00:01:26.890 --> 00:01:29.070
And that's what I want my message to be.

30

Or maybe I have something in Excel.

31
00:01:30.510 --> 00:01:33.650
Or maybe there's something in
a website that I need to copy and

32
00:01:33.650 --> 00:01:36.220
paste into my messages.

33
00:01:36.220 --> 00:01:41.127
So we're gonna go across those different
options, and throwing out those hey,

34
00:01:41.127 --> 00:01:45.963
that's a little different than that,
and hm, that's not carrying over, and

35

36

So I have OneDrive account with

00:01:51.846 --> 00:01:56.348

00:01:56.348 --> 00:01:59.910

00:01:59.910 --> 00:02:04.830
So this is the Alicetext.docx.

00:02:04.830 --> 00:02:07.320
That's a mouthful right there [LAUGH].

41
00:02:07.320 --> 00:02:10.520
And this is the one of Word online.

42
00:02:10.520 --> 00:02:13.780
So scrolling down I just wanted to show
you that there is a paragraph in here that

43
00:02:13.780 --> 00:02:18.390
has some of that local formatting, or
just character formatting we'll call it.

44
00:02:19.640 --> 00:02:21.640
That's what we'll call it,
because that's what it is.

45
00:02:21.640 --> 00:02:22.910
But we have it here.

46
00:02:22.910 --> 00:02:27.509
I also have the same document opened in my

47
00:02:27.509 --> 00:02:32.522
locally installed version of Word as well.

48
00:02:32.522 --> 00:02:34.330
Why do you think I'm doing that?

49
00:02:34.330 --> 00:02:38.430
Because I'm gonna show you just
a little bit of differences of

50
00:02:38.430 --> 00:02:42.970
copying from one place, and then copying
from another and what to do with it.

51
00:02:42.970 --> 00:02:46.556
And then how to control our paste options.

52
00:02:46.556 --> 00:02:51.510
Let's jump back down into Joey's mail and
start a new message.

53
00:02:52.510 --> 00:02:54.990
We're not gonna,
we could address it to somebody

54
00:02:54.990 --> 00:02:58.270

actually going to send it just yet.

55
00:02:58.270 --> 00:03:00.520
We'll come down into the message body.

56
00:03:00.520 --> 00:03:01.580
Don't forget that subject line.

57
00:03:01.580 --> 00:03:03.510
You know what, I sometimes do that.

58
00:03:03.510 --> 00:03:05.540
You don't wanna send a message
with no subject line.

59
00:03:05.540 --> 00:03:08.646
I've gotten that quite a few times and
people are like, mm, well,

60
00:03:08.646 --> 00:03:10.618
I guess we don't have
any subjects [LAUGH].

61
00:03:10.618 --> 00:03:13.210
>> Well, you know what I do when I
get a message with no subject line?

62
00:03:13.210 --> 00:03:17.820
I assume it's spam, mark it as spam,
throw it away, and well,

63
00:03:17.820 --> 00:03:18.590
I don't actually do that.

64
00:03:18.590 --> 00:03:20.503
But a lot of times I won't even read it,
or

65
00:03:20.503 --> 00:03:24.028
it'll get kind of pushed down after
things that don't have subject lines.

66
00:03:24.028 --> 00:03:27.856
So always put subject lines in there,
cuz if you're spending all this time

67
00:03:27.856 --> 00:03:31.712
to copy and paste from appropriate
sources, you want somebody to read it.

68
00:03:31.712 --> 00:03:34.554
>> [LAUGH] Yes,
that's kind of the email etiquette,

69
00:03:34.554 --> 00:03:37.060
and having a subject line that
actually means something.

70
00:03:37.060 --> 00:03:39.985
Not just hi,
cuz if I'm trying to find something,

71
00:03:39.985 --> 00:03:43.533
it's probably good to have
a nice descriptive subject line.

72
00:03:43.533 --> 00:03:46.735
But copy and paste or copy and
paste sounds good to me, and

73
00:03:46.735 --> 00:03:50.000
we'll jump down into our message body.

74
00:03:50.000 --> 00:03:53.490
So I want to get the text
out of the document.

75
00:03:53.490 --> 00:03:56.810
Let's start with a local copy of Word.

76
00:03:56.810 --> 00:03:59.394
And down, down, down,
there's nothing else to do.

77
00:03:59.394 --> 00:04:03.410
Let's select the text that I want to copy.

78
00:04:03.410 --> 00:04:06.500
We can right click, we can control C.

79
00:04:06.500 --> 00:04:09.360
I'm gonna right click so
you can see me doing this.

80
00:04:09.360 --> 00:04:13.460
And then I'm going to have that ready
to go on my clipboard, as it's called.

81
00:04:13.460 --> 00:04:18.905
We'll come down over to my message,
and I can right click and I can paste.

82
00:04:18.905 --> 00:04:23.468
Now notice here that the formatting
that was with that text,

83
00:04:23.468 --> 00:04:27.851
the red and the larger text,
the italicized purple text,

84
00:04:27.851 --> 00:04:33.412
is coming over into here, and you also
get something known as a smart tag.

85
00:04:33.412 --> 00:04:37.701
Remember this is where we have

86
00:04:37.701 --> 00:04:42.740
those assisted technologies.

87
00:04:42.740 --> 00:04:43.620
There you go.

88
00:04:43.620 --> 00:04:44.192
I did it right.

89
00:04:44.192 --> 00:04:46.250
I could see it, you were like,
I'm not gonna tell you.

90
00:04:46.250 --> 00:04:47.342
I'm gonna let you do it yourself.

91
00:04:47.342 --> 00:04:50.368
>> No I was going to let you flounder and
I would come in and

92
00:04:50.368 --> 00:04:52.665
swoop in and save you at the last moment.

93
00:04:52.665 --> 00:04:53.890
I wouldn't let you go down in flames.

94
00:04:55.310 --> 00:04:58.209
But you got it, I'm very proud of you.

95
00:04:58.209 --> 00:04:59.947
>> My oracle powers came out there too and

96
00:04:59.947 --> 00:05:02.430
I could just kinda reach it
out of your brain so [LAUGH].

97
00:05:02.430 --> 00:05:03.883
So, I have this here and

98
00:05:03.883 --> 00:05:07.900
this is also very common across
all of our Office product as well.

99
00:05:07.900 --> 00:05:12.839
Of paste options,
they are not as extensive if you

100
00:05:12.839 --> 00:05:18.270
are using Word or
a local copy of any of these products.

101
00:05:18.270 --> 00:05:22.369
But it does have the ones of,
paste as is P.

102
00:05:22.369 --> 00:05:25.975
[LAUGH] Just straight up paste like I did,
I pasted the text.

103
00:05:25.975 --> 00:05:31.187
But then there's also ones where
I have paste simple HTML and

104
00:05:31.187 --> 00:05:33.750
I also have paste as text.

105
00:05:33.750 --> 00:05:38.790
And this one where I usually like to
go to a lot, because a lot of times,

106
00:05:38.790 --> 00:05:43.100
I don't want it to retain
the formatting that it came over with.

107
00:05:43.100 --> 00:05:46.140
This is especially true if
I'm copying from a webpage,

108
00:05:46.140 --> 00:05:48.154
which I'll show you in a little bit.

109
00:05:48.154 --> 00:05:53.749
That's why I remember HTML, right,
we're picking a webpage that has HTML and

110
00:05:53.749 --> 00:05:59.370
we're putting it into a web based email
system that is also in HTML formatting.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne take a look at a few advanced mail features in Outlook on the Web. Specific topics covered here includes: Importance, Sensitivity, Delivery Receipt, Read Receipt, Options not available in Office 365, and Options not available in Outlook.com.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne take a look at a few advanced mail features in Outlook on the Web. Specific topics covered here includes: Importance icon, Read Receipt, Email Expiration, Voting, Mentions, and Undo Send.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explore the litany of ways in which you can organize, customize, and search in Outlook on the Web. Here they start with organization methods like focused inbox, using Filter, marking mail as "unread", selecting messages, flagging messages, pinning messages, and settings categories.
episodes.title: Organize, Customize and Search

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explore the litany of ways in which you can organize, customize, and search in Outlook on the Web. Here they start with customization methods like creating custom folders, reading pane settings, message list vs. conversations, read receipts, reply settings, attachment options, and mail layout.
episodes.title: Organize, Customize and Search Part 2

>> [LAUGH] Vonne,

547
00:27:09.522 --> 00:27:10.810
I think you did a great job.

548
00:27:10.810 --> 00:27:11.630
Don't worry about it.

549
00:27:11.630 --> 00:27:16.269
I think it was very thorough and very
clearly explained as well because I've

worked the help desk and got a lot of
these calls like, how do I do this?

551

Or this has happened and

How do I turn that off?

This is that show that people that want

555
00:27:30.620 --> 00:27:34.530

their interface to be more efficient for

556

557
00:27:36.300 --> 00:27:37.480
So I think you did a fantastic job.

558

559

We do appreciate you good folks out

We've come to the end of another great

[LAUGH] Signing off for OfficePro.TV,

00:27:53.286 --> 00:27:53.786
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne talk about Junk Mail. Here they define and describe what gets classified as Junk by the Junk Filter. They then show you how to block or allow items explicitly, look at client and admin level Control, marking messages as Junk, syncing with local versions of Outlook, and phishing.
episodes.title: Junk Mail
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

[MUSIC]

You don't really know what it does and

[BLANK AUDIO]

00:02:06.237 --> 00:02:07.197

A week goes by, I'm like, seriously?

43

Of course, I look in my junk mail.

44
00:02:15.470 --> 00:02:16.070
>> There it is.

45

I'm like, but I was just talking to him.

What's going on here?

So it's like right in the middle

49
00:02:27.793 --> 00:02:30.744

it was like this is not good,

00:02:30.744 --> 00:02:32.210

look and scan your emails and

55

57
00:02:52.481 --> 00:02:56.859

to say no, don't treat those as junk.

58
00:02:56.859 --> 00:03:00.007
Or maybe it gets into your inbox and

59
00:03:00.007 --> 00:03:03.460

60
00:03:03.460 --> 00:03:05.180
So you need to kind of teach it,

So great automatic features and

64

But then there's parts above you,

72
00:03:45.842 --> 00:03:48.885
I'm still not able to

73

So it might be on a higher level

74

75
00:03:57.134 --> 00:04:00.700

you need to be able to do.

76
00:04:00.700 --> 00:04:05.750
And then maybe even at the admin level,
I know there's third party apps that kind

77
00:04:05.750 --> 00:04:10.020
of catch things even outside before

78
00:04:10.020 --> 00:04:11.140

00:04:18.780 --> 00:04:22.800

So anyways, we digress but I do want to

I don't have to add them all to my list,

I wonder if that's, its basically

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explain Archiving and using the Archive folder in Web-based Outlook. They start by explaining what the Archive folder is, then they move on to Retention Policies, using Sweep, and general guidelines for archiving old messages.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne demonstrate how to create and edit contacts. They also cover contact lists, deleting contacts, and import and export options.

It's there, you just need to use

So just be aware of those differences,

00:31:59.800 --> 00:32:03.336

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explore the Calendar interface for Outlook on the Web. They show different views, identify events, look at event details, and change calendar settings. They also cover adding birthday and other interesting calendars as well as all the options in the calendar settings.
episodes.title: Calendar Interface

>> Feeling good out there, right?

651
00:30:05.834 --> 00:30:07.940
[LAUGH] It's circular,
it goes around, and up and down.

652
00:30:07.940 --> 00:30:09.110
It's like a carousel.

653
00:30:09.110 --> 00:30:11.422
Anyway, we're gonna leave
before we digress too far.

654
00:30:11.422 --> 00:30:12.560
>> Yeah [LAUGH].
>> Vonne, thanks so much for

655
00:30:12.560 --> 00:30:13.430
stopping by today and

656
00:30:13.430 --> 00:30:17.910
showing us how to use the calendar
features inside of Outlook on the web.

657
00:30:17.910 --> 00:30:19.220
But it does look like
we are out of time for

658
00:30:19.220 --> 00:30:23.210
this episode, so
we're forced to sign off for OfficePro.TV.

659
00:30:23.210 --> 00:30:24.180
We do thank you for watching.

660
00:30:24.180 --> 00:30:25.370
I've been you host, Daniel Lowrie.

661
00:30:25.370 --> 00:30:25.950
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

662
00:30:25.950 --> 00:30:27.344
>> And we'll see you next time.

663
00:30:27.344 --> 00:30:33.665
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore creating and managing appointments.
episodes.title: Create and Manage Appointments
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

>> Yeah, it's like I've been hiding or

>> But not really.

We had an appointment today for

00:01:18.972 --> 00:01:21.069

>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm guessing just the label that used

>> Yeah.
>> So my programmer mind's like,

00:01:56.245 --> 00:01:57.926
all right so we have an event class.

And then below that we have inheriting

00:02:02.195 --> 00:02:02.807
>> Yeah.

42

>> And how are they different.

00:02:04.230 --> 00:02:05.811
They're called something different,

>> Yes, it doesn't get that complicated.

45
00:02:06.864 --> 00:02:07.799
>> Okay.

46
00:02:07.799 --> 00:02:11.748
>> [LAUGH] What a difference is at meeting

that's the biggest difference, okay.

48
00:02:14.970 --> 00:02:16.599
>> Yeah.
>> So you're inviting attendees.

49
00:02:16.599 --> 00:02:18.382
Attendees, when you're doing a meeting.

50
00:02:18.382 --> 00:02:20.140
An appointment is really just for you,

51
00:02:20.140 --> 00:02:22.866
you're talking about keeping
it up in your noodle, right.

52
00:02:22.866 --> 00:02:28.382
So that would be your own noodle,
calendar, appointment, keeper.

53
00:02:28.382 --> 00:02:31.400
So you'd have to tell
yourself what I'm doing.

54
00:02:31.400 --> 00:02:33.172
And so that's the biggest difference.

55
00:02:33.172 --> 00:02:36.882
So sorry, that kind of like talking about
the terminology and where we're at.

56

00:02:39.613 --> 00:02:41.983
I have my calendar for Joey.

58
00:02:41.983 --> 00:02:45.353
I still have my kitty cats,

59
00:02:45.353 --> 00:02:50.493
And then today you can see that I do have

00:02:50.493 --> 00:02:51.970

00:02:51.970 --> 00:02:55.300

00:02:59.517 --> 00:03:02.332

But you can see that I have

So I'm gonna show you how

I'd like to go ahead and

And I don't know if Alex

>> [LAUGH]
>> We'll leave that alone for now.

77
00:03:35.710 --> 00:03:38.101
We'll just set a date and

suggestions and its nice because when we

00:03:42.083 --> 00:03:46.013

its going to give us a map for all that.

80
00:03:46.013 --> 00:03:47.471
How about we go ahead and do that now.

00:03:47.471 --> 00:03:48.997
How do I make an appointment for

myself knowing that I'm gonna be going

00:03:52.831 --> 00:03:56.810
You can either right click on the date
that you're going to be creating

00:03:56.810 --> 00:03:58.710
appointment, go to New.

00:03:58.710 --> 00:04:01.302
You could also double click on that day,

That whole kind of using that

Now the difference is if you double click
on the day it will usually default to

00:04:12.627 --> 00:04:14.220

Well, you know what,
as soon as I say that,

that's the local version of Outlook

But that's okay, we know that we can have

00:04:25.454 --> 00:04:26.791

00:04:26.791 --> 00:04:30.011

[LAUGH] You can tell I've been

And I'm like no, that's Daniel,
cuz they hear our voices.

00:04:48.471 --> 00:04:50.530
>> Yeah.
>> And we have similar vocal ranges so,

103
00:04:50.530 --> 00:04:51.552
>> You definitely do.

104
00:04:51.552 --> 00:04:53.088
>> I don't take any offense to that.

105
00:04:53.088 --> 00:04:54.614
>> [LAUGH]
>> Awesome.

106
00:04:54.614 --> 00:04:57.122
All right, so now we're going

Now this is where if you have a global

Now some other ones that you're seeing in

I also have Amalie Arena that's because

And if you had resources within your

00:05:35.821 --> 00:05:37.852
A, B, C, and D, or what have you.

00:05:37.852 --> 00:05:41.848
If you just start typing in the first

will go ahead and give you those options.

120
00:05:46.403 --> 00:05:50.342
So we're talking about some

00:05:50.342 --> 00:05:55.035
And just because I've been thinking

00:05:55.035 --> 00:05:57.021
how about we type in Moe's?

00:05:57.021 --> 00:06:00.350
And now you can see that Moe's is

00:06:00.350 --> 00:06:02.891
it's kinda pull up, okay, that's the one.

00:06:02.891 --> 00:06:05.751
R Cherough which is actually not
the one closest to us but hey,

00:06:05.751 --> 00:06:07.131
we can go over to that one too.

00:06:07.131 --> 00:06:10.932
So you can see that it's kinda a little

128
00:06:10.932 --> 00:06:13.821
It might ask you the first time

00:06:13.821 --> 00:06:16.580

130
00:06:16.580 --> 00:06:22.042
But geolocation you know a lot

131
00:06:22.042 --> 00:06:23.061
I will get this.

132
00:06:23.061 --> 00:06:27.262
>> You will get my name right, and
yes typically you're going to allow for

134
00:06:31.827 --> 00:06:36.145
And now if you deny essentially all your
geolocation services is gonna be x down.

135
00:06:36.145 --> 00:06:39.892
If you did wanna change those things
those are browser specific setting,

136
00:06:39.892 --> 00:06:43.893
typically does your change using the
little padlock next to your address bar.

137
00:06:43.893 --> 00:06:45.843
But that's outside the scope for this.

138
00:06:45.843 --> 00:06:50.216
So just keep in mind, if you're not seeing
things populated with a geo located

139
00:06:50.216 --> 00:06:54.802

140
00:06:54.802 --> 00:06:56.527
>> That's a really good
point because you're like,

141
00:06:56.527 --> 00:06:58.222
mine's not coming up with
anything around here.

00:06:58.222 --> 00:07:00.162
So that's a really good
thing to know about.

143
00:07:00.162 --> 00:07:02.509
So we're gonna go ahead and

00:07:02.509 --> 00:07:05.944
now again if you didn't want to

145
00:07:05.944 --> 00:07:10.612
Maybe I don't even have it connected,

00:07:10.612 --> 00:07:11.471

147
00:07:11.471 --> 00:07:13.640
Because Tim's want to talk
about the weather with us or

148
00:07:13.640 --> 00:07:14.922
something like of that effect.

149
00:07:14.922 --> 00:07:19.973
So, I'll just go ahead and say Tim's

150
00:07:19.973 --> 00:07:20.802
Okay yeah, close enough.

151
00:07:20.802 --> 00:07:24.080
So you can see that it is trying
to pull something from there but

00:07:24.080 --> 00:07:26.932
it doesn't have to be map related,
so that's okay.

153
00:07:26.932 --> 00:07:29.670
All right, so
what date is it starting on now?

154
00:07:29.670 --> 00:07:33.473
That's because I double clicked on that

00:07:33.473 --> 00:07:37.105
I realized it was supposed to be next

00:07:37.105 --> 00:07:39.243

00:07:39.243 --> 00:07:43.866
Now this is a single time appointment

00:07:43.866 --> 00:07:47.253

00:07:47.253 --> 00:07:49.751
So I could have it start and

00:07:49.751 --> 00:07:51.702

161
00:07:51.702 --> 00:07:55.650
Maybe we're going to a conference

00:07:55.650 --> 00:07:59.783
So then I can have it span

163
00:07:59.783 --> 00:08:04.927
It starts at 8AM and ends at 5PM on

164
00:08:04.927 --> 00:08:05.920
So you have that.

165
00:08:05.920 --> 00:08:08.706
Some other options over here,
that if this was an all day appointment.

166
00:08:08.706 --> 00:08:11.400
Hey, maybe we're gonna go
to lunch all day, right?

167
00:08:11.400 --> 00:08:12.950
We go ahead and check that off.

168
00:08:12.950 --> 00:08:16.980
Notice that then my times, my start and
end date times aren't going to be

169
00:08:16.980 --> 00:08:20.620

this is the whole day.

170
00:08:20.620 --> 00:08:24.300
So that's something you might wanna go
ahead and consider if you need it done.

171
00:08:24.300 --> 00:08:26.290
If you have it set to private,

00:08:26.290 --> 00:08:30.510
that's how it's showing up on

When it's private, it kind of

Not everybody can see those details.

175

And when you get into like Calendar

00:08:47.300 --> 00:08:51.060
Because we all use our work calendars but
there might be something that you're gonna

180
00:08:54.340 --> 00:08:57.039
So you can go ahead and

181
00:08:58.350 --> 00:09:01.780
And then if you need to go ahead and set
it to a different time zone if I'm telling

00:09:01.780 --> 00:09:06.980
this to be like a specific time,
it will then like change it for

00:09:06.980 --> 00:09:11.950
you automatically cuz you're in Eastern
time zone in the sense that well we are.

184
00:09:11.950 --> 00:09:14.370
And we had it set that that's what it is.

185
00:09:14.370 --> 00:09:18.161
But my appointment I know is
gonna be 5PM pacific time,

186
00:09:18.161 --> 00:09:22.274
well then I would change it to
whatever it is in my timezone and

187
00:09:22.274 --> 00:09:25.838
then put it at I guess it
would be 8PM on my schedule.

188
00:09:25.838 --> 00:09:29.620
So that's just like when you're entering
the time of the appointment and

189
00:09:29.620 --> 00:09:31.024
then how it changes there.

190
00:09:31.024 --> 00:09:36.397
All right, so let's go ahead and
change this from, we'll go 11:30 to 1:30,

191
00:09:36.397 --> 00:09:39.823
make sure we have all traffic and
everything like that.

192
00:09:39.823 --> 00:09:40.460
All right, and

193
00:09:40.460 --> 00:09:43.580
this is where we have [INAUDIBLE]
is this a recurring appointment?

194
00:09:43.580 --> 00:09:45.670
So this one,
we are not gonna have it repeat for

195
00:09:45.670 --> 00:09:48.130
right now, just a one time thing.

196
00:09:48.130 --> 00:09:52.197
But notice if I did have it something
like, hey I need to have a manager's

197
00:09:52.197 --> 00:09:56.666
meeting every Friday for the next however
many times, you can go ahead and go and

198
00:09:56.666 --> 00:09:59.060
set that recurrence, that pattern.

199
00:09:59.060 --> 00:10:00.650
We'll look at that in a little bit.

200
00:10:00.650 --> 00:10:02.930
Now, you can have multiple calendars.

201
00:10:02.930 --> 00:10:06.450
Now, this one, this reunion tour,
by the way, this is a group calendar, so

202
00:10:06.450 --> 00:10:08.050
that's something a little bit different.

203
00:10:08.050 --> 00:10:11.120
We have a whole episode on groups that
kind of explain that a little bit more,

204
00:10:11.120 --> 00:10:14.860
but you can have more than
one type of calendar.

205
00:10:14.860 --> 00:10:19.583
So that's where you can set which
calender is supposed to be to.

206
00:10:19.583 --> 00:10:20.975
And then the reminder,

207
00:10:20.975 --> 00:10:24.975
I love me some reminders cuz I need to
always remind myself is where I'm at.

208
00:10:24.975 --> 00:10:32.249
So what iteration or what time do
you want the reminder to be set.

209
00:10:32.249 --> 00:10:35.976
And then how it's gonna be shown
in your calendar again when you

00:22:39.350 --> 00:22:42.529
I wanna copy this and then just go
ahead and put it somewhere else.

433
00:22:43.690 --> 00:22:47.640
I can't find how to do that,
I will just tell you that right now.

434
00:22:47.640 --> 00:22:50.990
I go to try and right click,
I try to Google it.

435
00:22:50.990 --> 00:22:53.060
So at the time of this recording,

436
00:22:53.060 --> 00:22:57.830
I cannot find a way that I want to
copy this and put it somewhere else.

437
00:22:57.830 --> 00:23:01.900
So in case anybody else is thinking
about that, if you're like me, like,

438
00:23:01.900 --> 00:23:04.950
wouldn't it be easier if it's the same
thing, I just kinda wanna move it over?

439
00:23:06.150 --> 00:23:07.390
I guess you could just go ahead and

440
00:23:07.390 --> 00:23:10.140
make an occurrence,
like make it, you know what?

441
00:23:10.140 --> 00:23:12.580
I was thinking about this.

442
00:23:12.580 --> 00:23:14.980
>> Sometimes just talking
it through is helpful.

443
00:23:14.980 --> 00:23:19.370
Now, I wanna make sure that
we're all on the same page here.

444
00:23:19.370 --> 00:23:22.480
There's not an easily accessible
right click, just copy over.

445
00:23:22.480 --> 00:23:23.260
>> Correct.

446
00:23:23.260 --> 00:23:25.830
>> If you're thinking to yourself,
whoa, couldn't I just reenter it, and

447
00:23:25.830 --> 00:23:27.100
technically that's a copy?

448
00:23:27.100 --> 00:23:30.970
Yeah, tomato, tomato, but
there's not something through the UI

449
00:23:30.970 --> 00:23:36.010
that allows me to go right-click,
copy to this calendar, or copy to

450
00:23:36.010 --> 00:23:40.270
wherever you need to copy it to, that's
what we're ultimately talking about.

451
00:23:40.270 --> 00:23:42.054
>> And I just thought of this.

452
00:23:42.054 --> 00:23:46.170
What if you did this,
what if you edit the appointment,

453
00:23:46.170 --> 00:23:51.774
make it a reoccurring for a daily, or
a weekly, just once, one iteration,

454
00:23:51.774 --> 00:23:57.661
then take that iteration and then edit
that And had it moved to a different date.

455
00:23:57.661 --> 00:24:00.600
That's how you can kinda copy it,
couldn't you?

456
00:24:00.600 --> 00:24:03.930
>> Yeah,
I guess you could possibly copy that like,

457
00:24:03.930 --> 00:24:05.610
even copying within the calendar.

458
00:24:05.610 --> 00:24:07.140
>> Yeah.

459
00:24:07.140 --> 00:24:08.082
>> That might work.

460
00:24:08.082 --> 00:24:09.807
That might, you never know.

461
00:24:09.807 --> 00:24:12.349
Sometimes you just gotta, please work.

462
00:24:12.349 --> 00:24:13.261
>> [LAUGH] Yes.

463
00:24:13.261 --> 00:24:14.525
>> But that is a good idea.

464
00:24:14.525 --> 00:24:15.975
That's definitely worth a try.

465
00:24:15.975 --> 00:24:20.265
>> I honestly thought of it as we're
talking about it in this whole episode.

466
00:24:20.265 --> 00:24:23.208
So hey, that's something that
I'm thinking I might try.

467
00:24:23.208 --> 00:24:25.220
So anyways, that's where we're going to.

468
00:24:25.220 --> 00:24:28.475
The other thing, everything that we've
been talking about is the same in our

469
00:24:28.475 --> 00:24:31.610
outlook.com, our free
version of our outlook.

470
00:24:31.610 --> 00:24:34.791
And then the other one I wanted
to go with is birthdays, right?

471
00:24:34.791 --> 00:24:37.470
We talked about I in
the birthday calendar.

472
00:24:37.470 --> 00:24:42.089
It is a setting within your
calendar settings, your options.

473
00:24:42.089 --> 00:24:46.130
So if you wanted to add a birthday,
just come back down into here,

474
00:24:46.130 --> 00:24:49.440
you can see that I can go up and
do a new birthday event.

475
00:24:49.440 --> 00:24:52.860
So it is in the drop down
item right here if you want.

476
00:24:52.860 --> 00:24:57.661
The other thing you can do, is if you
right click on the calendar on the list,

477
00:24:57.661 --> 00:24:59.402
you can add a new birthday.

478
00:24:59.402 --> 00:25:02.896
And then you can put in the first and
the last name and then the birthday and

479
00:25:02.896 --> 00:25:06.616
then if you want a reminder cuz it's
always good to be reminded of somebody's

480
00:25:06.616 --> 00:25:07.500
birthday.

481
00:25:07.500 --> 00:25:09.236
Cuz then when they show up like yes,
it's my birthday.

482
00:25:09.236 --> 00:25:12.100
And I'm like, I knew that.

483
00:25:12.100 --> 00:25:13.511
No I didn't, I totally forgot.

484
00:25:13.511 --> 00:25:17.480
[LAUGH] So it's always good to go
ahead and put that as a reminder.

485
00:25:17.480 --> 00:25:19.203
I'm gonna go ahead and discard that.

486
00:25:19.203 --> 00:25:20.850
And I'm gonna close out the birthdays.

487
00:25:20.850 --> 00:25:23.640
And so that is pretty much
all the things I can show you

488
00:25:23.640 --> 00:25:25.110
about creating an appointment.

489
00:25:25.110 --> 00:25:30.480
It really comes down to you organizing
your life and your calendar and

490
00:25:30.480 --> 00:25:34.390
making sure that all those color
codings and all those categories

491
00:25:34.390 --> 00:25:38.330
mean something to you, because those
categories do go across all of Outlook.

492
00:25:38.330 --> 00:25:41.641
So if you start using green in
your calendar for one thing and

493
00:25:41.641 --> 00:25:46.491
then green in your email as another thing,
that's where it can be a little confusing.

494
00:25:46.491 --> 00:25:49.120
So try to kinda keep
that across the board.

495
00:25:49.120 --> 00:25:52.650
I mean, and I have people that, like I
think I have said it in other episodes.

496
00:25:52.650 --> 00:25:56.420
They use their calendar like to the hills,
right?

497
00:25:56.420 --> 00:26:00.580
They put everything in there to make sure
that they don't skip anything because like

498
00:26:00.580 --> 00:26:04.730
you said sometimes, sometimes our noodle
doesn't always noodle the right way.

499
00:26:04.730 --> 00:26:10.180
So write it down and then hopefully,
you can stay on track.

500
00:26:10.180 --> 00:26:13.100
>> Well Vonne, I'm definitely going to try
to implement a few of these in my life

501
00:26:13.100 --> 00:26:17.930
because if nothing else, sometimes they're
like, hey, you forgot about coming to

502
00:26:17.930 --> 00:26:21.940
your doctor's appointment or
coming to someone's birthday.

503
00:26:21.940 --> 00:26:25.610
I was busy and really I just forgot.

504
00:26:25.610 --> 00:26:27.240
So I definitely I need to work on these.

505
00:26:27.240 --> 00:26:31.550
I'm pretty sure the color coding may
end up being a huge time sync to me cuz

506
00:26:31.550 --> 00:26:36.580
I would always try to keep
those as very particular to me.

507
00:26:36.580 --> 00:26:41.300
Now we figured out how to manage our own
life, but we still got more where we need

508
00:26:41.300 --> 00:26:44.130
to figure out how to manage our lives
along with other people's as well.

509
00:26:44.130 --> 00:26:47.350
So definitely join us back for
more Outlook on the Web.

510
00:26:47.350 --> 00:26:49.070
But for now, we're gonna go ahead and
finish this one up.

511
00:26:49.070 --> 00:26:52.310
So signing off for OfficeProTV,
I've been your host, Justin Dennison.

512
00:26:52.310 --> 00:26:53.164
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

513
00:26:53.164 --> 00:26:55.125
>> And we'll see you next time.

514
00:26:55.125 --> 00:27:00.225
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore creating and managing meetings.
episodes.title: Create and Manage Meetings
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.726 --> 00:00:15.870
Greetings everyone and welcome to another
exciting episode of OfficePro.TV.

3
00:00:15.870 --> 00:00:18.760
I'm your host, Justin Dennison, and
in today's episode, well, we're continuing

4
00:00:18.760 --> 00:00:23.340
our trek on Outlook in the web, on the
web, I'll get that right in just a moment.

5
00:00:23.340 --> 00:00:28.060
In particular, we're looking at organizing
a bunch of people together using meetings.

6
00:00:28.060 --> 00:00:32.433
And luckily, we have the expert in
that very topic, Miss Vonne Smith.

7
00:00:32.433 --> 00:00:34.543
How you doing today, Vonne?

8
00:00:34.543 --> 00:00:36.079
>> I'm so good, I love your introductions.

9
00:00:36.079 --> 00:00:36.710
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

10
00:00:36.710 --> 00:00:38.712
>> We're in the web or on the web, for

11
00:00:38.712 --> 00:00:39.610
the web.

12
00:00:39.610 --> 00:00:40.150
>> Yeah, who knows?

13
00:00:40.150 --> 00:00:41.639
You're a professional cat herder.

14
00:00:41.639 --> 00:00:43.300
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm pretty sure those are the same

15
00:00:43.300 --> 00:00:45.670
as organizing people, so
we're good to go, right?

16
00:00:45.670 --> 00:00:48.990
>> I did have to schedule a meeting
of the cats this weekend,

17
00:00:48.990 --> 00:00:52.780
because they had to get their flea
control, and they didn't like that.

18
00:00:52.780 --> 00:00:54.620
But they didn't know they were invited.

19
00:00:54.620 --> 00:00:55.670
It was just like, get on the counter!

20
00:00:55.670 --> 00:00:56.590
And they're like-
>> It would be

21
00:00:56.590 --> 00:00:57.941
really weird if your cat had calendars.

22
00:00:57.941 --> 00:00:59.300
>> [LAUGH]
>> And you were like,

23
00:00:59.300 --> 00:01:00.330
your calendar's booked?

24
00:01:00.330 --> 00:01:02.450
No, I'm gonna need you to go ahead and
come in now.

25
00:01:02.450 --> 00:01:06.450
>> I think they're on their own schedule,
because if the food is not in front of

26
00:01:06.450 --> 00:01:09.400
them at a certain time,
things just start coming off the counter.

27
00:01:09.400 --> 00:01:11.010
>> Yeah, be like whoops.

28
00:01:11.010 --> 00:01:12.535
>> Yeah.
>> I know you like that, but it's broke.

29
00:01:12.535 --> 00:01:13.599
Where's my food at, right?

30
00:01:13.599 --> 00:01:14.161
>> Exactly.

31
00:01:14.161 --> 00:01:15.062
I've got your attention?

32
00:01:15.062 --> 00:01:15.833
Come on, feed me.

33
00:01:15.833 --> 00:01:17.211
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Meow.

34
00:01:17.211 --> 00:01:18.120
>> Exactly.

35
00:01:18.120 --> 00:01:20.890
So yes, we are gonna be talking
about some meeting here.

36

And we did find out in the other episode,
if you had watched

the difference between an appointment and

00:01:27.180 --> 00:01:31.012

So that's gonna be the biggest difference,
so if you've watched that episode then

much going to be a repeat.

41
00:01:37.851 --> 00:01:42.459
But we're gonna do the whole having

00:01:42.459 --> 00:01:45.340

43
00:01:45.340 --> 00:01:48.780
Luckily, of course, as you know,
I have control of three different people.

44
00:01:48.780 --> 00:01:52.685
I am Justin, and
[LAUGH] now with you being here.

45
00:01:52.685 --> 00:01:54.130
>> [LAUGH] Now it just got awkward.

46
00:01:54.130 --> 00:01:57.040
Really, hold on,
I was not given the appropriate memo.

47
00:01:57.040 --> 00:02:01.025
You should have sent out an invite to

48
00:02:01.025 --> 00:02:02.610
>> [LAUGH] Exactly.

49
00:02:02.610 --> 00:02:06.030
So JT and Joey and Lance.

50
00:02:06.030 --> 00:02:07.326
And so we're going to have,

00:02:07.326 --> 00:02:11.340
what you have is the meeting organizer
if you are the one creating the meeting.

52
00:02:11.340 --> 00:02:16.090
And then we'll also see if you are the one
being invited to a meeting and

53
00:02:16.090 --> 00:02:17.390
how that all works.

54
00:02:17.390 --> 00:02:20.430
It is nice having control of
lots of different people and

55
00:02:20.430 --> 00:02:21.840
all of their accounts.

56
00:02:21.840 --> 00:02:23.526
Yeah.
They're all me anyway so, so

57
00:02:23.526 --> 00:02:25.941
[LAUGH] why don't we
come on down into here.

58
00:02:25.941 --> 00:02:26.467
And you know what?

59
00:02:26.467 --> 00:02:31.374
I did wanna go ahead and before we start
into the meeting, I wanted to throw

00:02:31.374 --> 00:02:36.070

me honestly in our last episode.

61
00:02:36.070 --> 00:02:39.040
When we were creating appointments,
there was something about forwarding.

00:02:39.040 --> 00:02:44.130
And why don't I go ahead and show you here
that in the Outlook on the web version

63
00:02:44.130 --> 00:02:48.310
right here, remember I tried to open
this and I kind of fumbled a little bit.

64
00:02:48.310 --> 00:02:51.440
I was like, hey, this didn't work but
it really should work.

65
00:02:51.440 --> 00:02:53.240
Well, I tested it out again and

66
00:02:53.240 --> 00:02:56.860
it's just not wanting to work
in this particular browser.

67
00:02:56.860 --> 00:02:59.480
I'll be completely honest,
I did not check this in Edge.

68
00:02:59.480 --> 00:03:02.780
But so far, in all these things
that have been happening,

69
00:03:02.780 --> 00:03:06.470
the browser versions hasn't been
a big factor into this, okay?

70
00:03:06.470 --> 00:03:08.892
But the whole forwarding an appointment.

71
00:03:08.892 --> 00:03:11.550
All right, so Joey went ahead and

00:03:11.550 --> 00:03:17.070
forwarded his, I actually forwarded
the Appliance Shopping right over here.

00:03:17.070 --> 00:03:19.900
And you can see, and
this was the other one.

74
00:03:19.900 --> 00:03:22.900
You can come into here and
you can preview it, and

75
00:03:22.900 --> 00:03:27.000
I can see that this is the Marketing
meeting, and it says bring your notes.

76
00:03:27.000 --> 00:03:30.320
And I can download it, but you can already
see, I tried this a couple of times.

77
00:03:30.320 --> 00:03:32.060
It just downloads as this weird file and

78
00:03:32.060 --> 00:03:34.920
it's not being able to
just add to my calendar.

79
00:03:34.920 --> 00:03:37.041
And you and
I were talking about this off camera,

80
00:03:37.041 --> 00:03:39.784
even while you're not using Outlook
you get this sent to you and

81
00:03:39.784 --> 00:03:42.610
you can just add it right to your
account and everything is fine.

82
00:03:42.610 --> 00:03:43.670
>> Yeah, it's weird.

83
00:03:43.670 --> 00:03:45.760
Most of the time,
I've never had an issue with,

84
00:03:45.760 --> 00:03:49.720
it doesn't matter whether it comes from
an Outlook calendar, from an iCalender or

85
00:03:49.720 --> 00:03:51.370
from a Gmail calendar or
whatever it may be.

86
00:03:51.370 --> 00:03:56.080
When it comes to me, I usually the ability
to add to calendar from within the email

87
00:03:56.080 --> 00:03:57.750
and it adds it to my calendar.

88
00:03:57.750 --> 00:03:59.930
Even if I'm not necessarily
an invited person,

89
00:03:59.930 --> 00:04:03.050
it's just someone sending me hey
here's what's up about this event.

90
00:04:03.050 --> 00:04:05.666
>> Yeah.
And you had talked about an ISC, or

91
00:04:05.666 --> 00:04:09.980
ICS file,
it's an International that's not it.

92
00:04:09.980 --> 00:04:13.749
It's something about like it's a universal
calendar format, and we will talk about

93
00:04:13.749 --> 00:04:17.360
these different types of file formats
when we get into shared calendars.

94
00:04:17.360 --> 00:04:19.260
But yeah,
I just found it very interesting.

95
00:04:19.260 --> 00:04:23.930
But I wanted to show you that in the local
installation of Outlook what happens, and

96
00:04:23.930 --> 00:04:25.690
that's what I was kinda going on.

97
00:04:25.690 --> 00:04:26.880
It's just gonna work the same.

98
00:04:26.880 --> 00:04:27.682
And well guess what?

99
00:04:27.682 --> 00:04:30.280
[LAUGH] Don't ever assume,
cuz you know what happens.

100
00:04:30.280 --> 00:04:34.540
So you can see that if I open this in
the local version, it opens up and

101
00:04:34.540 --> 00:04:36.830
I can copy it to my calendar.

102
00:04:36.830 --> 00:04:39.000
So it's like somebody's
forwarded this to me,

103
00:04:39.000 --> 00:04:43.830
in a sense that they want me to add it
to mine, it's right here in the local.

104
00:04:43.830 --> 00:04:46.650
I just don't see it as fluid,

105
00:04:46.650 --> 00:04:51.110
if you want to say, or streamlined
in the Outlook on the web version.

106
00:04:51.110 --> 00:04:54.938
I'm not saying it's not possible, but
for me and today, the time of recording,

107
00:04:54.938 --> 00:04:57.060
[LAUGH] it's not wanting
to play very nicely.

108
00:04:57.060 --> 00:05:00.680
So, I just wanted to throw that out
there for you guys to let you know.

109
00:05:01.690 --> 00:05:02.730
Stranger things have happened.

110
00:05:02.730 --> 00:05:06.125
Maybe it works just fine for
you, and maybe its just me.

111
00:05:06.125 --> 00:05:07.212
That happens a lot.

112
00:05:07.212 --> 00:05:10.330
[LAUGH] But just wanted to
throw that out there to you.

113
00:05:10.330 --> 00:05:12.830
Okay, so let's go back over to Joey.

114
00:05:12.830 --> 00:05:16.280
And Joey is going to create a meeting.

115
00:05:16.280 --> 00:05:19.490
We're going to have a working lunch.

116
00:05:19.490 --> 00:05:24.740
And he is going to invite JT and
Lance to this lunch.

117
00:05:24.740 --> 00:05:27.830
So that's where we're going to
be as the meeting organizers.

118
00:05:27.830 --> 00:05:30.490
So let's go ahead and
create a new calendar event.

119
00:05:30.490 --> 00:05:31.080
Okay.

120
00:05:31.080 --> 00:05:36.390
And I'm going to schedule it for
this Friday.

121
00:05:36.390 --> 00:05:42.070
So we're gonna say Working Lunch,
let's go ahead and put a space in there.

122
00:05:42.070 --> 00:05:46.175
And we'll go ahead and put My Office.

123
00:05:46.175 --> 00:05:47.635
Wow, look at all those.

124
00:05:47.635 --> 00:05:49.760
[LAUGH] So we have My Office and

125
00:05:49.760 --> 00:05:54.390
we're going to do this for
this Friday, which is the 25th.

126
00:05:54.390 --> 00:05:58.760
And we will go for,
let's do 11:00 to 1:00.

127
00:05:58.760 --> 00:06:01.050
So we'll have a nice long lunch,
and there we go.

128
00:06:01.050 --> 00:06:04.470
All the other stuff, I can go ahead and
do the reminders and

129
00:06:04.470 --> 00:06:05.740
I can say bring your notes.

130
00:06:05.740 --> 00:06:07.730
All these different things
that I could go through.

131
00:06:07.730 --> 00:06:10.770
I can add an email reminder as well for

132
00:06:10.770 --> 00:06:14.450
the day before and
send it to all the attendees.

133
00:06:14.450 --> 00:06:18.570
So, again,
I'm kind of going over it really quickly,

134
00:06:18.570 --> 00:06:21.140
because we did cover
this in the appointment.

135
00:06:21.140 --> 00:06:22.370
If you haven't watched that episode,

136
00:06:22.370 --> 00:06:27.210
definitely go ahead and go back to that
particular one and check this out.

137
00:06:27.210 --> 00:06:31.160
Now, the other thing is I could come
up here and add a Skype meeting.

138
00:06:31.160 --> 00:06:36.200
Now, the only thing that's going to do
is just go ahead and add a link for

139
00:06:36.200 --> 00:06:40.410
you to be able to have
an online Skype meeting.

140
00:06:40.410 --> 00:06:43.410
So it's nothing super fancy besides,
watch,

141
00:06:43.410 --> 00:06:46.660
if I go ahead and
get some online meeting information.

142
00:06:46.660 --> 00:06:48.890
And I do have Skype for
Business already set up, and

143
00:06:48.890 --> 00:06:50.950
everything on my account that way.

144

Now we're gonna go ahead and

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore sharing calendars with others, in particular, adding secondary calendars, importing ICS files, as well as published HTML calendars from others. They also explore export and publish their own calendars.
episodes.title: Share Calendars

WEBVTT

[MUSIC]

[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, but you are correct.

organization through osmosis?

>> Yeah,
it's vicarious organizational practices.

22
00:01:11.400 --> 00:01:13.250
I should coin that term.

23
00:01:13.250 --> 00:01:14.510
>> I know, I like that.

24
00:01:14.510 --> 00:01:15.240
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

25
00:01:15.240 --> 00:01:16.764
>> But that's how I roll, Vonne.

26
00:01:16.764 --> 00:01:17.492
>> [LAUGH] I like that.

27
00:01:17.492 --> 00:01:20.710
If it's working for you,
you keep on going with that.

28
00:01:20.710 --> 00:01:22.280
So we're gonna-
>> Toot toot.

So we're gonna go ahead and show you guys

So it depends on how you

But when we get into

00:02:26.320 --> 00:02:28.350

Hey, can I borrow that piece of paper?

Are you going to give me
back a piece of paper?

Or can I borrow some money with

00:02:36.258 --> 00:02:38.925
Eh, it's used, depending on context,

00:02:38.925 --> 00:02:42.747

00:02:42.747 --> 00:02:44.945
And that's kind of the vibe

00:02:44.945 --> 00:02:45.815

I'm just gonna take it and

58

59
00:02:58.115 --> 00:02:59.100
>> [LAUGH] Wow.

60
00:02:59.100 --> 00:03:01.355
>> That sounds like a vicarious

61
00:03:01.355 --> 00:03:03.571
>> [LAUGH] Exactly.

62

So it's one of those, you know what, I

We did talk about this

Now this is something to where

But if you think about somebody that has

You know, you traveling cats,

85

we'll go with I have some of those.

86

That seems to have escalated in

88

But yes, I own show cats.

[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

Because your work people need

00:04:45.990 --> 00:04:48.320
So if you just come over

00:04:48.320 --> 00:04:52.980

That's the one who I've delegated to
go ahead and talk on my behalf, okay.

252
00:13:43.497 --> 00:13:46.807
Now, as the person managing

be careful because this is again,
where am I?

254
00:13:49.600 --> 00:13:50.290
Who am I?

255
00:13:50.290 --> 00:13:51.350
What am I doing?

256
00:13:51.350 --> 00:13:56.420
This is for Lance or JT Now somebody
probably wouldn't title it that way.

257
00:13:56.420 --> 00:13:58.450
You have to look at who's required.

258
00:13:58.450 --> 00:14:01.580
Is this for me, as me Joey?

00:14:01.580 --> 00:14:05.367
Or is this for me for

262
00:14:13.206 --> 00:14:16.131

263

00:14:26.620 --> 00:14:28.710
Justin doesn't see any

I'm just gonna go ahead and keep it

Now, and then it goes on there and
so, if I as Joy come over here,

00:14:39.436 --> 00:14:44.891
two Justin's counter there it is,
Lance 4 JT, has been added as JT,

00:14:44.891 --> 00:14:49.810
all right, if I come over here,
and then, yep, it's on his.

00:14:49.810 --> 00:14:54.049
So that's where Justin's like, hey, I got

So that's what I wanted to demonstrate

there's a lot of clicking back and

00:15:00.884 --> 00:15:05.120

Like I said, Justin can always go back

00:15:09.580 --> 00:15:12.290

And I could go ahead and

And then it will go ahead and add and

00:16:01.064 --> 00:16:05.352
>> Well, Vonne, it seems that outlook.com
has all the kind of bodies that

we've that's for as I look on the lib.

>> For the most part, I mean, the delegate

So here at Lance,

notice that down here right there,

since Vonne, talking about myself in

that Vonne gave access to Lance to edit,
then Lance can go ahead and make

an event from here and then Vonne will see

301
00:16:50.724 --> 00:16:54.730
We got so people into this little episode,

302
00:16:54.730 --> 00:16:59.160
There's a lot of sharing, and

00:16:59.160 --> 00:17:03.283
Hopefully, you got the whole gist of it

yes outlook.com does have a lot

So that's nice if you have

00:17:08.963 --> 00:17:12.838

And if outlook.com does the trick,

Sometimes it' like, well I have to have a

So you do need to kinda,

[LAUGH]
>> I thought we were bursting, kinda,

I'm was able to start dancing and

>> Let's kinda tidy this one up.

320
00:17:43.640 --> 00:17:47.230
Now, Vonne, you've definitely shown

But a lot of the core

328
00:18:07.445 --> 00:18:11.044
I'm almost sold, but I don't know

329

330
00:18:15.443 --> 00:18:18.210
But that's gonna go ahead and

331
00:18:18.210 --> 00:18:21.220
But we do have more Outlook on

332
00:18:21.220 --> 00:18:22.830

333
00:18:22.830 --> 00:18:26.730
But for now, signing off for OFFICEPRO.TV
I've been you host Justin Anderson

334
00:18:26.730 --> 00:18:27.730
>> And I'm Yvonne Smith.

335
00:18:27.730 --> 00:18:29.838
>> We'll see you next time.

336
00:18:29.838 --> 00:18:33.058
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explain tasks and how to use them effectively. They explain the different types of tasks, creating and editing tasks, and organizing tasks with sort and filter options. They also cover how notes work in Outlook on the Web.
episodes.title: Tasks and Notes
